referringExpression: Julia called Mr Crawfords attention to her sister by saying

quoteText:
I do not like to see Miss
Bertram so near the altar.
subQuotationList: ['I do not like to see Miss\nBertram so near the altar.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
referringExpression: Mr Crawford smiled his acquiescence and stepping forward to Maria said in a voice which she only could hear

quoteText: If he would give her away?
subQuotationList: ['If he would give her away?']
speaker: Maria Bertram
referringExpression: the lady instinctively moved a step or two but recovering herself in a moment affected to laugh and asked him

quoteText: I am afraid I should do it very awkwardly,
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid I should do it very awkwardly,']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Upon my word, it is really a pity that it should not take place
directly, if we had but a proper licence, for here we are altogether,
and nothing in the world could be more snug and pleasant.
subQuotationList: ['Upon my word, it is really a pity that it should not take place\ndirectly, if we had but a proper licence, for here we are altogether,\nand nothing in the world could be more snug and pleasant.']
speaker: Julia Bertram
referringExpression: Julia joining them at the moment carried on the joke
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']]]

quoteText: If Edmund were but in orders!
subQuotationList: ['If Edmund were but in orders!']
speaker: Julia Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
My dear Edmund, if you were but in
orders now, you might perform the ceremony directly. How unlucky that
you are not ordained; Mr. Rushworth and Maria are quite ready.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Edmund, if you were but in\norders now, you might perform the ceremony directly. How unlucky that\nyou are not ordained; Mr. Rushworth and Maria are quite ready.']
speaker: Julia Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
How distressed she will be at what
she said just now,
subQuotationList: ['How distressed she will be at what\nshe said just now,']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: Ordained! what, are you to be a clergyman?
subQuotationList: ['Ordained!', 'what, are you to be a clergyman?']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Yes; I shall take orders soon after my father's return   probably at
Christmas.
subQuotationList: ["Yes; I shall take orders soon after my father's return   probably at\nChristmas."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
If I had known this before, I would have spoken of the
cloth with more respect,
subQuotationList: ['If I had known this before, I would have spoken of the\ncloth with more respect,']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: Miss Crawford rallying her spirits and recovering her complexion replied

quoteText:
For
if, we are _too_ long going over the
house, we shall not have time for what is to be done out of doors. It
is past two, and we are to dine at five.
subQuotationList:
['For
if,', 'we are _too_ long going over the
house, we shall not have time for what is to be done out of doors. It
is past two, and we are to dine at five.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']]]

quoteText:
Suppose we turn down here for the present, Here are the greatest
number of our plants, and here are the curious pheasants.
subQuotationList: ['Suppose we turn down here for the present,', 'Here are the greatest\nnumber of our plants, and here are the curious pheasants.']
speaker: Mrs. Rushworth
addressees: ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']], []]

quoteText:
Query, whether we may not find
something to employ us here before we go farther? I see walls of great
promise. Mr. Rushworth, shall we summon a council on this lawn?
subQuotationList: ['Query,', 'whether we may not find\nsomething to employ us here before we go farther? I see walls of great\npromise. Mr. Rushworth, shall we summon a council on this lawn?']
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']]]

quoteText:
James, I believe the wilderness will
be new to all the party. The Miss Bertrams have never seen the
wilderness yet.
subQuotationList: ['James,', 'I believe the wilderness will\nbe new to all the party. The Miss Bertrams have never seen the\nwilderness yet.']
speaker: Mrs. Rushworth
addressees: ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']
referringExpression: said Mrs Rushworth to her son

quoteText:
This is insufferably hot, Shall any of us object to being
comfortable? Here is a nice little wood, if one can but get into it.
What happiness if the door should not be locked! but of course it is;
for in these great places the gardeners are the only people who can go
where they like.
subQuotationList:
['This is insufferably hot,', 'Shall any of us object to being
comfortable? Here is a nice little wood, if one can but get into it.
What happiness if the door should not be locked! but of course it is;
for in these great places the gardeners are the only people who can go
where they like.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
So you are to be a clergyman, Mr.
Bertram. This is rather a surprise to me.
subQuotationList: ['So you are to be a clergyman, Mr.\nBertram. This is rather a surprise to me.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Why should it surprise you? You must suppose me designed for some
profession, and might perceive that I am neither a lawyer, nor a
soldier, nor a sailor.
subQuotationList: ['Why should it surprise you? You must suppose me designed for some\nprofession, and might perceive that I am neither a lawyer, nor a\nsoldier, nor a sailor.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Very true; but, in short, it had not occurred to me. And you know
there is generally an uncle or a grandfather to leave a fortune to the
second son.
subQuotationList: ['Very true; but, in short, it had not occurred to me. And you know\nthere is generally an uncle or a grandfather to leave a fortune to the\nsecond son.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
A very praiseworthy practice, but not quite universal.
I am one of the exceptions, and _being_ one, must do something for
myself.
subQuotationList: ['A very praiseworthy practice,', 'but not quite universal.\nI am one of the exceptions, and _being_ one, must do something for\nmyself.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
But why are you to be a clergyman? I thought _that_ was always the lot
of the youngest, where there were many to chuse before him.
subQuotationList: ['But why are you to be a clergyman? I thought _that_ was always the lot\nof the youngest, where there were many to chuse before him.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: Do you think the church itself never chosen, then?
subQuotationList: ['Do you think the church itself never chosen, then?']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
_Never_ is a black word. But yes, in the _never_ of conversation,
which means _not_ _very_ _often_, I do think it. For what is to be done
in the church? Men love to distinguish themselves, and in either of the
other lines distinction may be gained, but not in the church. A
clergyman is nothing.
subQuotationList:
['_Never_ is a black word. But yes, in the _never_ of conversation,
which means _not_ _very_ _often_, I do think it. For what is to be done
in the church? Men love to distinguish themselves, and in either of the
other lines distinction may be gained, but not in the church. A
clergyman is nothing.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
The _nothing_ of conversation has its gradations, I hope, as well as
the _never_. A clergyman cannot be high in state or fashion. He must
not head mobs, or set the ton in dress. But I cannot call that
situation nothing which has the charge of all that is of the first
importance to mankind, individually or collectively considered,
temporally and eternally, which has the guardianship of religion and
morals, and consequently of the manners which result from their
influence. No one here can call the _office_ nothing. If the man who
holds it is so, it is by the neglect of his duty, by foregoing its just
importance, and stepping out of his place to appear what he ought not
to appear.
subQuotationList:
['The _nothing_ of conversation has its gradations, I hope, as well as
the _never_. A clergyman cannot be high in state or fashion. He must
not head mobs, or set the ton in dress. But I cannot call that
situation nothing which has the charge of all that is of the first
importance to mankind, individually or collectively considered,
temporally and eternally, which has the guardianship of religion and
morals, and consequently of the manners which result from their
influence. No one here can call the _office_ nothing. If the man who
holds it is so, it is by the neglect of his duty, by foregoing its just
importance, and stepping out of his place to appear what he ought not
to appear.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
_You_ assign greater consequence to the clergyman than one has been
used to hear given, or than I can quite comprehend. One does not see
much of this influence and importance in society, and how can it be
acquired where they are so seldom seen themselves? How can two sermons
a week, even supposing them worth hearing, supposing the preacher to
have the sense to prefer Blair's to his own, do all that you speak of?
govern the conduct and fashion the manners of a large congregation for
the rest of the week? One scarcely sees a clergyman out of his pulpit.
subQuotationList:
["_You_ assign greater consequence to the clergyman than one has been
used to hear given, or than I can quite comprehend. One does not see
much of this influence and importance in society, and how can it be
acquired where they are so seldom seen themselves? How can two sermons
a week, even supposing them worth hearing, supposing the preacher to
have the sense to prefer Blair's to his own, do all that you speak of?
govern the conduct and fashion the manners of a large congregation for
the rest of the week? One scarcely sees a clergyman out of his pulpit."]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: _You_ are speaking of London, _I_ am speaking of the nation at large.
subQuotationList: ['_You_ are speaking of London, _I_ am speaking of the nation at large.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: The metropolis, I imagine, is a pretty fair sample of the rest.
subQuotationList: ['The metropolis, I imagine, is a pretty fair sample of the rest.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Not, I should hope, of the proportion of virtue to vice throughout the
kingdom. We do not look in great cities for our best morality. It is
not there that respectable people of any denomination can do most good;
and it certainly is not there that the influence of the clergy can be
most felt. A fine preacher is followed and admired; but it is not in
fine preaching only that a good clergyman will be useful in his parish
and his neighbourhood, where the parish and neighbourhood are of a size
capable of knowing his private character, and observing his general
conduct, which in London can rarely be the case. The clergy are lost
there in the crowds of their parishioners. They are known to the
largest part only as preachers. And with regard to their influencing
public manners, Miss Crawford must not misunderstand me, or suppose I
mean to call them the arbiters of good-breeding, the regulators of
refinement and courtesy, the masters of the ceremonies of life. The
_manners_ I speak of might rather be called _conduct_, perhaps, the
result of good principles; the effect, in short, of those doctrines
which it is their duty to teach and recommend; and it will, I believe,
be everywhere found, that as the clergy are, or are not what they ought
to be, so are the rest of the nation.
subQuotationList:
['Not, I should hope, of the proportion of virtue to vice throughout the
kingdom. We do not look in great cities for our best morality. It is
not there that respectable people of any denomination can do most good;
and it certainly is not there that the influence of the clergy can be
most felt. A fine preacher is followed and admired; but it is not in
fine preaching only that a good clergyman will be useful in his parish
and his neighbourhood, where the parish and neighbourhood are of a size
capable of knowing his private character, and observing his general
conduct, which in London can rarely be the case. The clergy are lost
there in the crowds of their parishioners. They are known to the
largest part only as preachers. And with regard to their influencing
public manners, Miss Crawford must not misunderstand me, or suppose I
mean to call them the arbiters of good-breeding, the regulators of
refinement and courtesy, the masters of the ceremonies of life. The
_manners_ I speak of might rather be called _conduct_, perhaps, the
result of good principles; the effect, in short, of those doctrines
which it is their duty to teach and recommend; and it will, I believe,
be everywhere found, that as the clergy are, or are not what they ought
to be, so are the rest of the nation.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: Certainly,
subQuotationList: ['Certainly,']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
There, you have quite convinced Miss Price
already.
subQuotationList: ['There,', 'you have quite convinced Miss Price\nalready.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: I wish I could convince Miss Crawford too.
subQuotationList: ['I wish I could convince Miss Crawford too.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: I do not think you ever will,
subQuotationList: ['I do not think you ever will,']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
I am
just as much surprised now as I was at first that you should intend to
take orders. You really are fit for something better. Come, do change
your mind. It is not too late. Go into the law.
subQuotationList:
['I am
just as much surprised now as I was at first that you should intend to
take orders. You really are fit for something better. Come, do change
your mind. It is not too late. Go into the law.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Go into the law! With as much ease as I was told to go into this
wilderness.
subQuotationList: ['Go into the law! With as much ease as I was told to go into this\nwilderness.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Now you are going to say something about law being the worst
wilderness of the two, but I forestall you; remember, I have
forestalled you.
subQuotationList: ['Now you are going to say something about law being the worst\nwilderness of the two, but I forestall you; remember, I have\nforestalled you.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
You need not hurry when the object is only to prevent my saying a
_bon_ _mot_, for there is not the least wit in my nature. I am a very
matter-of-fact, plain-spoken being, and may blunder on the borders of a
repartee for half an hour together without striking it out.
subQuotationList:
['You need not hurry when the object is only to prevent my saying a
_bon_ _mot_, for there is not the least wit in my nature. I am a very
matter-of-fact, plain-spoken being, and may blunder on the borders of a
repartee for half an hour together without striking it out.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I wonder that I should be tired with only
walking in this sweet wood; but the next time we come to a seat, if it
is not disagreeable to you, I should be glad to sit down for a little
while.
subQuotationList:
['I wonder that I should be tired with only
walking in this sweet wood; but the next time we come to a seat, if it
is not disagreeable to you, I should be glad to sit down for a little
while.']
speaker: Fanny Price
referringExpression: Fanny made the first interruption by saying

quoteText:
My dear Fanny, how thoughtless I have been! I hope you are not very tired. Perhaps, my other companion may do me the honour of
taking an arm.
subQuotationList: ['My dear Fanny,', 'how thoughtless I have been! I hope you are not very tired. Perhaps,', 'my other companion may do me the honour of\ntaking an arm.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: Thank you, but I am not at all tired.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, but I am not at all tired.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
You scarcely touch me, You do not make me of any use. What
a difference in the weight of a woman's arm from that of a man! At
Oxford I have been a good deal used to have a man lean on me for the
length of a street, and you are only a fly in the comparison.
subQuotationList:
['You scarcely touch me,', "You do not make me of any use. What
a difference in the weight of a woman's arm from that of a man! At
Oxford I have been a good deal used to have a man lean on me for the
length of a street, and you are only a fly in the comparison."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I am really not tired, which I almost wonder at; for we must have
walked at least a mile in this wood. Do not you think we have?
subQuotationList: ['I am really not tired, which I almost wonder at; for we must have\nwalked at least a mile in this wood. Do not you think we have?']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: Not half a mile,
subQuotationList: ['Not half a mile,']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Oh! you do not consider how much we have wound about. We have taken
such a very serpentine course, and the wood itself must be half a mile
long in a straight line, for we have never seen the end of it yet since
we left the first great path.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! you do not consider how much we have wound about. We have taken
such a very serpentine course, and the wood itself must be half a mile
long in a straight line, for we have never seen the end of it yet since
we left the first great path.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund']]]

quoteText:
But if you remember, before we left that first great path, we saw
directly to the end of it. We looked down the whole vista, and saw it
closed by iron gates, and it could not have been more than a furlong in
length.
subQuotationList:
['But if you remember, before we left that first great path, we saw
directly to the end of it. We looked down the whole vista, and saw it
closed by iron gates, and it could not have been more than a furlong in
length.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund']]]

quoteText:
Oh! I know nothing of your furlongs, but I am sure it is a very long
wood, and that we have been winding in and out ever since we came into
it; and therefore, when I say that we have walked a mile in it, I must
speak within compass.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! I know nothing of your furlongs, but I am sure it is a very long
wood, and that we have been winding in and out ever since we came into
it; and therefore, when I say that we have walked a mile in it, I must
speak within compass.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Edmund']]]

quoteText: We have been exactly a quarter of an hour here, Do you think we are walking four miles an hour?
subQuotationList: ['We have been exactly a quarter of an hour here,', 'Do you think we are walking four miles an hour?']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Oh! do not attack me with your watch. A watch is always too fast or
too slow. I cannot be dictated to by a watch.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! do not attack me with your watch. A watch is always too fast or\ntoo slow. I cannot be dictated to by a watch.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
I am afraid you are very tired, Fanny, why would not you speak sooner? This will be a bad day's amusement for
you if you are to be knocked up. Every sort of exercise fatigues her so
soon, Miss Crawford, except riding.
subQuotationList: ['I am afraid you are very tired, Fanny,', "why would not you speak sooner? This will be a bad day's amusement for\nyou if you are to be knocked up. Every sort of exercise fatigues her so\nsoon, Miss Crawford, except riding."]
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText:
How abominable in you, then, to let me engross her horse as I did all
last week! I am ashamed of you and of myself, but it shall never happen
again.
subQuotationList: ['How abominable in you, then, to let me engross her horse as I did all\nlast week! I am ashamed of you and of myself, but it shall never happen\nagain.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
_Your_ attentiveness and consideration makes me more sensible of my
own neglect. Fanny's interest seems in safer hands with you than with
me.
subQuotationList: ["_Your_ attentiveness and consideration makes me more sensible of my\nown neglect. Fanny's interest seems in safer hands with you than with\nme."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
That she should be tired now, however, gives me no surprise; for there
is nothing in the course of one's duties so fatiguing as what we have
been doing this morning: seeing a great house, dawdling from one room
to another, straining one's eyes and one's attention, hearing what one
does not understand, admiring what one does not care for. It is
generally allowed to be the greatest bore in the world, and Miss Price
has found it so, though she did not know it.
subQuotationList:
["That she should be tired now, however, gives me no surprise; for there
is nothing in the course of one's duties so fatiguing as what we have
been doing this morning: seeing a great house, dawdling from one room
to another, straining one's eyes and one's attention, hearing what one
does not understand, admiring what one does not care for. It is
generally allowed to be the greatest bore in the world, and Miss Price
has found it so, though she did not know it."]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
I shall soon be rested, to sit in the shade on a fine
day, and look upon verdure, is the most perfect refreshment.
subQuotationList: ['I shall soon be rested,', 'to sit in the shade on a fine\nday, and look upon verdure, is the most perfect refreshment.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
I must move, resting fatigues me. I have looked across the ha-ha till I
am weary. I must go and look through that iron gate at the same view,
without being able to see it so well.
subQuotationList: ['I must move,', 'resting fatigues me. I have looked across the ha-ha till I\nam weary. I must go and look through that iron gate at the same view,\nwithout being able to see it so well.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Now, Miss Crawford, if you will look up
the walk, you will convince yourself that it cannot be half a mile
long, or half half a mile.
subQuotationList: ['Now, Miss Crawford, if you will look up\nthe walk, you will convince yourself that it cannot be half a mile\nlong, or half half a mile.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: It is an immense distance, I see _that_ with a glance.
subQuotationList: ['It is an immense distance,', 'I see _that_ with a glance.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: Miss Price all alone
subQuotationList: ['Miss Price all alone']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: My dear Fanny, how comes this?
subQuotationList: ['My dear Fanny, how comes this?']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
Poor dear Fanny, how ill you have been used by them! You had better have staid
with us.
subQuotationList: ['Poor dear Fanny,', 'how ill you have been used by them! You had better have staid\nwith us.']
speaker: Maria Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
It is undoubtedly the best thing we can do now, as we are so far from
the house already,
subQuotationList: ['It is undoubtedly the best thing we can do now, as we are so far from\nthe house already,']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Yes, there is nothing else to be done. But now, sincerely, do not you
find the place altogether worse than you expected?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, there is nothing else to be done. But now, sincerely, do not you\nfind the place altogether worse than you expected?']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
No, indeed, far otherwise. I find it better, grander, more complete in
its style, though that style may not be the best. And to tell you the
truth,
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, far otherwise. I find it better, grander, more complete in\nits style, though that style may not be the best. And to tell you the\ntruth,']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
I do not think that _I_ shall ever see
Sotherton again with so much pleasure as I do now. Another summer will
hardly improve it to me.
subQuotationList: ['I do not think that _I_ shall ever see\nSotherton again with so much pleasure as I do now. Another summer will\nhardly improve it to me.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
You are too much a
man of the world not to see with the eyes of the world. If other people
think Sotherton improved, I have no doubt that you will.
subQuotationList: ['You are too much a\nman of the world not to see with the eyes of the world. If other people\nthink Sotherton improved, I have no doubt that you will.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
I am afraid I am not quite so much the man of the world as might be
good for me in some points. My feelings are not quite so evanescent,
nor my memory of the past under such easy dominion as one finds to be
the case with men of the world.
subQuotationList:
['I am afraid I am not quite so much the man of the world as might be
good for me in some points. My feelings are not quite so evanescent,
nor my memory of the past under such easy dominion as one finds to be
the case with men of the world.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
You
seemed to enjoy your drive here very much this morning. I was glad to
see you so well entertained. You and Julia were laughing the whole
way.
subQuotationList:
['You
seemed to enjoy your drive here very much this morning. I was glad to
see you so well entertained. You and Julia were laughing the whole
way.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
Were we? Yes, I believe we were; but I have not the least recollection
at what. Oh! I believe I was relating to her some ridiculous stories of
an old Irish groom of my uncle's. Your sister loves to laugh.
subQuotationList: ["Were we? Yes, I believe we were; but I have not the least recollection\nat what. Oh! I believe I was relating to her some ridiculous stories of\nan old Irish groom of my uncle's. Your sister loves to laugh."]
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText: You think her more light-hearted than I am?
subQuotationList: ['You think her more light-hearted than I am?']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
More easily amused, consequently, you know, better company. I could not have hoped to entertain you with Irish
anecdotes during a ten miles' drive.
subQuotationList: ['More easily amused,', 'consequently, you know,', "better company. I could not have hoped to entertain you with Irish\nanecdotes during a ten miles' drive."]
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Naturally, I believe, I am as lively as Julia, but I have more to
think of now.
subQuotationList: ['Naturally, I believe, I am as lively as Julia, but I have more to\nthink of now.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
You have, undoubtedly; and there are situations in which very high
spirits would denote insensibility. Your prospects, however, are too
fair to justify want of spirits. You have a very smiling scene before
you.
subQuotationList:
['You have, undoubtedly; and there are situations in which very high
spirits would denote insensibility. Your prospects, however, are too
fair to justify want of spirits. You have a very smiling scene before
you.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Do you mean literally or figuratively? Literally, I conclude. Yes,
certainly, the sun shines, and the park looks very cheerful. But
unluckily that iron gate, that ha-ha, give me a feeling of restraint
and hardship.    I cannot get out,' as the starling said.
subQuotationList:
["Do you mean literally or figuratively? Literally, I conclude. Yes,
certainly, the sun shines, and the park looks very cheerful. But
unluckily that iron gate, that ha-ha, give me a feeling of restraint
and hardship.    I cannot get out,' as the starling said."]
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText: Mr. Rushworth is so long fetching this key!
subQuotationList: ['Mr. Rushworth is so long fetching this key!']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
And for the world you would not get out without the key and without
Mr. Rushworth's authority and protection, or I think you might with
little difficulty pass round the edge of the gate, here, with my
assistance; I think it might be done, if you really wished to be more
at large, and could allow yourself to think it not prohibited.
subQuotationList:
["And for the world you would not get out without the key and without
Mr. Rushworth's authority and protection, or I think you might with
little difficulty pass round the edge of the gate, here, with my
assistance; I think it might be done, if you really wished to be more
at large, and could allow yourself to think it not prohibited."]
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Prohibited! nonsense! I certainly can get out that way, and I will.
Mr. Rushworth will be here in a moment, you know; we shall not be out
of sight.
subQuotationList: ['Prohibited! nonsense! I certainly can get out that way, and I will.\nMr. Rushworth will be here in a moment, you know; we shall not be out\nof sight.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
Or if we are, Miss Price will be so good as to tell him that he will
find us near that knoll: the grove of oak on the knoll.
subQuotationList: ['Or if we are, Miss Price will be so good as to tell him that he will\nfind us near that knoll: the grove of oak on the knoll.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
You will hurt yourself, Miss Bertram, you
will certainly hurt yourself against those spikes; you will tear your
gown; you will be in danger of slipping into the ha-ha. You had better
not go.
subQuotationList:
['You will hurt yourself, Miss Bertram,', 'you
will certainly hurt yourself against those spikes; you will tear your
gown; you will be in danger of slipping into the ha-ha. You had better
not go.']
speaker: Fanny Price
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram']], [['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
Thank you,
my dear Fanny, but I and my gown are alive and well, and so good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you,\nmy dear Fanny, but I and my gown are alive and well, and so good-bye.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
Heyday!
Where are the others? I thought Maria and Mr. Crawford were with you.
subQuotationList: ['Heyday!\nWhere are the others? I thought Maria and Mr. Crawford were with you.']
speaker: Julia Bertram
referringExpression: Julia who hot and out of breath and with a look of disappointment cried out on seeing her

quoteText: A pretty trick, upon my word! I cannot see them anywhere,
subQuotationList: ['A pretty trick, upon my word! I cannot see them anywhere,']
speaker: Julia Bertram

quoteText:
But they cannot be very far off, and I think I
am equal to as much as Maria, even without help.
subQuotationList: ['But they cannot be very far off, and I think I\nam equal to as much as Maria, even without help.']
speaker: Julia Bertram

quoteText:
But, Julia, Mr. Rushworth will be here in a moment with the key. Do
wait for Mr. Rushworth.
subQuotationList: ['But, Julia, Mr. Rushworth will be here in a moment with the key. Do\nwait for Mr. Rushworth.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Not I, indeed. I have had enough of the family for one morning. Why,
child, I have but this moment escaped from his horrible mother. Such a
penance as I have been enduring, while you were sitting here so
composed and so happy! It might have been as well, perhaps, if you had
been in my place, but you always contrive to keep out of these
scrapes.
subQuotationList:
['Not I, indeed. I have had enough of the family for one morning. Why,
child, I have but this moment escaped from his horrible mother. Such a
penance as I have been enduring, while you were sitting here so
composed and so happy! It might have been as well, perhaps, if you had
been in my place, but you always contrive to keep out of these
scrapes.']
speaker: Julia Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Yes, yes, we saw him. He was posting away as if upon life and death,
and could but just spare time to tell us his errand, and where you all
were.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, yes, we saw him. He was posting away as if upon life and death,\nand could but just spare time to tell us his errand, and where you all\nwere.']
speaker: Julia Bertram

quoteText: It is a pity he should have so much trouble for nothing.
subQuotationList: ['It is a pity he should have so much trouble for nothing.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
_That_ is Miss Maria's concern. I am not obliged to punish myself for
_her_ sins. The mother I could not avoid, as long as my tiresome aunt
was dancing about with the housekeeper, but the son I _can_ get away
from.
subQuotationList:
["_That_ is Miss Maria's concern. I am not obliged to punish myself for
_her_ sins. The mother I could not avoid, as long as my tiresome aunt
was dancing about with the housekeeper, but the son I _can_ get away
from."]
speaker: Julia Bertram
mentionTextsList: [['Miss Maria', 'her', 'The mother I could not avoid', 'my tiresome aunt', 'the son']]

quoteText:
They desired me to stay   my cousin Maria charged me to say that you
would find them at that knoll, or thereabouts.
subQuotationList: ['They desired me to stay   my cousin Maria charged me to say that you\nwould find them at that knoll, or thereabouts.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
I do not believe I shall go any farther, I see
nothing of them. By the time I get to the knoll they may be gone
somewhere else. I have had walking enough.
subQuotationList: ['I do not believe I shall go any farther,', 'I see\nnothing of them. By the time I get to the knoll they may be gone\nsomewhere else. I have had walking enough.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText: I am very sorry, it is very unlucky.
subQuotationList: ['I am very sorry,', 'it is very unlucky.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
I think they might as well have staid
for me,
subQuotationList: ['I think they might as well have staid\nfor me,']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText: Miss Bertram thought you would follow her.
subQuotationList: ['Miss Bertram thought you would follow her.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: I should not have had to follow her if she had staid.
subQuotationList: ['I should not have had to follow her if she had staid.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText:
Pray, Miss Price, are you such a great admirer of this Mr.
Crawford as some people are? For my part, I can see nothing in him.
subQuotationList: ['Pray, Miss Price, are you such a great admirer of this Mr.\nCrawford as some people are? For my part, I can see nothing in him.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText: I do not think him at all handsome.
subQuotationList: ['I do not think him at all handsome.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Handsome! Nobody can call such an undersized man handsome. He is not
five foot nine. I should not wonder if he is not more than five foot
eight. I think he is an ill-looking fellow. In my opinion, these
Crawfords are no addition at all. We did very well without them.
subQuotationList:
['Handsome! Nobody can call such an undersized man handsome. He is not
five foot nine. I should not wonder if he is not more than five foot
eight. I think he is an ill-looking fellow. In my opinion, these
Crawfords are no addition at all. We did very well without them.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText:
If I had made any difficulty about fetching the key, there might have
been some excuse, but I went the very moment she said she wanted it.
subQuotationList: ['If I had made any difficulty about fetching the key, there might have\nbeen some excuse, but I went the very moment she said she wanted it.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText:
Nothing could be more obliging than your manner, I am sure, and I dare
say you walked as fast as you could; but still it is some distance, you
know, from this spot to the house, quite into the house; and when
people are waiting, they are bad judges of time, and every half minute
seems like five.
subQuotationList:
['Nothing could be more obliging than your manner, I am sure, and I dare
say you walked as fast as you could; but still it is some distance, you
know, from this spot to the house, quite into the house; and when
people are waiting, they are bad judges of time, and every half minute
seems like five.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
It is a pity you should not join
them. They expected to have a better view of the house from that part
of the park, and will be thinking how it may be improved; and nothing
of that sort, you know, can be settled without you.
subQuotationList:
['It is a pity you should not join
them. They expected to have a better view of the house from that part
of the park, and will be thinking how it may be improved; and nothing
of that sort, you know, can be settled without you.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Well, if you really
think I had better go: it would be foolish to bring the key for
nothing.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'if you really\nthink I had better go: it would be foolish to bring the key for\nnothing.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText:
I hope
I am not to lose my companion, unless she is afraid of the evening air
in so exposed a seat.
subQuotationList: ['I hope\nI am not to lose my companion, unless she is afraid of the evening air\nin so exposed a seat.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Well, Fanny, this has been a fine day for you, upon my word, Nothing but pleasure from
beginning to end! I am sure you ought to be very much obliged to your
aunt Bertram and me for contriving to let you go. A pretty good day's
amusement you have had!
subQuotationList:
['Well, Fanny, this has been a fine day for you, upon my word,', "Nothing but pleasure from
beginning to end! I am sure you ought to be very much obliged to your
aunt Bertram and me for contriving to let you go. A pretty good day's
amusement you have had!"]
speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
I think _you_ have
done pretty well yourself, ma'am. Your lap seems full of good things,
and here is a basket of something between us which has been knocking my
elbow unmercifully.
subQuotationList:
["I think _you_ have
done pretty well yourself, ma'am. Your lap seems full of good things,
and here is a basket of something between us which has been knocking my
elbow unmercifully."]
speaker: Maria Bertram
referringExpression: Maria was just discontented enough to say
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris']]]

quoteText:
My dear, it is only a beautiful little heath, which that nice old
gardener would make me take; but if it is in your way, I will have it
in my lap directly. There, Fanny, you shall carry that parcel for me;
take great care of it: do not let it fall; it is a cream cheese, just
like the excellent one we had at dinner. Nothing would satisfy that
good old Mrs. Whitaker, but my taking one of the cheeses. I stood out
as long as I could, till the tears almost came into her eyes, and I
knew it was just the sort that my sister would be delighted with. That
Mrs. Whitaker is a treasure! She was quite shocked when I asked her
whether wine was allowed at the second table, and she has turned away
two housemaids for wearing white gowns. Take care of the cheese, Fanny.
Now I can manage the other parcel and the basket very well.
subQuotationList:
['My dear, it is only a beautiful little heath, which that nice old
gardener would make me take; but if it is in your way, I will have it
in my lap directly. There, Fanny, you shall carry that parcel for me;
take great care of it: do not let it fall; it is a cream cheese, just
like the excellent one we had at dinner. Nothing would satisfy that
good old Mrs. Whitaker, but my taking one of the cheeses. I stood out
as long as I could, till the tears almost came into her eyes, and I
knew it was just the sort that my sister would be delighted with. That
Mrs. Whitaker is a treasure! She was quite shocked when I asked her
whether wine was allowed at the second table, and she has turned away
two housemaids for wearing white gowns. Take care of the cheese, Fanny.
Now I can manage the other parcel and the basket very well.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText: What else have you been spunging?
subQuotationList: ['What else have you been spunging?']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
Spunging, my dear! It is nothing but four of those beautiful
pheasants' eggs, which Mrs. Whitaker would quite force upon me: she
would not take a denial. She said it must be such an amusement to me,
as she understood I lived quite alone, to have a few living creatures
of that sort; and so to be sure it will. I shall get the dairymaid to
set them under the first spare hen, and if they come to good I can have
them moved to my own house and borrow a coop; and it will be a great
delight to me in my lonely hours to attend to them. And if I have good
luck, your mother shall have some.
subQuotationList:
["Spunging, my dear! It is nothing but four of those beautiful
pheasants' eggs, which Mrs. Whitaker would quite force upon me: she
would not take a denial. She said it must be such an amusement to me,
as she understood I lived quite alone, to have a few living creatures
of that sort; and so to be sure it will. I shall get the dairymaid to
set them under the first spare hen, and if they come to good I can have
them moved to my own house and borrow a coop; and it will be a great
delight to me in my lonely hours to attend to them. And if I have good
luck, your mother shall have some."]
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText:
How happy Mr. Rushworth looks! He is thinking of
November.
subQuotationList: ['How happy Mr. Rushworth looks! He is thinking of\nNovember.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: she suddenly revived it by turning round towards the group and saying

quoteText: Your father's return will be a very interesting event.
subQuotationList: ["Your father's return will be a very interesting event."]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
It will, indeed, after such an absence; an absence not only long, but
including so many dangers.
subQuotationList: ['It will, indeed, after such an absence; an absence not only long, but\nincluding so many dangers.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
It will be the forerunner also of other interesting events: your
sister's marriage, and your taking orders.
subQuotationList: ["It will be the forerunner also of other interesting events: your\nsister's marriage, and your taking orders."]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Don't be affronted, but it does put me in mind
of some of the old heathen heroes, who, after performing great exploits
in a foreign land, offered sacrifices to the gods on their safe
return.
subQuotationList:
["Don't be affronted,", 'but it does put me in mind
of some of the old heathen heroes, who, after performing great exploits
in a foreign land, offered sacrifices to the gods on their safe
return.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
There is no sacrifice in the case, it is entirely her own
doing.
subQuotationList: ['There is no sacrifice in the case,', 'it is entirely her own\ndoing.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Oh yes I know it is. I was merely joking. She has done no more than
what every young woman would do; and I have no doubt of her being
extremely happy. My other sacrifice, of course, you do not understand.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes I know it is. I was merely joking. She has done no more than\nwhat every young woman would do; and I have no doubt of her being\nextremely happy. My other sacrifice, of course, you do not understand.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
My taking orders, I assure you, is quite as voluntary as Maria's
marrying.
subQuotationList: ["My taking orders, I assure you, is quite as voluntary as Maria's\nmarrying."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
It is fortunate that your inclination and your father's convenience
should accord so well. There is a very good living kept for you, I
understand, hereabouts.
subQuotationList: ["It is fortunate that your inclination and your father's convenience\nshould accord so well. There is a very good living kept for you, I\nunderstand, hereabouts."]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: Which you suppose has biassed me?
subQuotationList: ['Which you suppose has biassed me?']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: But _that_ I am sure it has not,
subQuotationList: ['But _that_ I am sure it has not,']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Thank you for your good word, Fanny, but it is more than I would
affirm myself. On the contrary, the knowing that there was such a
provision for me probably did bias me. Nor can I think it wrong that it
should. There was no natural disinclination to be overcome, and I see
no reason why a man should make a worse clergyman for knowing that he
will have a competence early in life. I was in safe hands. I hope I
should not have been influenced myself in a wrong way, and I am sure my
father was too conscientious to have allowed it. I have no doubt that I
was biased, but I think it was blamelessly.
subQuotationList:
['Thank you for your good word, Fanny, but it is more than I would
affirm myself. On the contrary, the knowing that there was such a
provision for me probably did bias me. Nor can I think it wrong that it
should. There was no natural disinclination to be overcome, and I see
no reason why a man should make a worse clergyman for knowing that he
will have a competence early in life. I was in safe hands. I hope I
should not have been influenced myself in a wrong way, and I am sure my
father was too conscientious to have allowed it. I have no doubt that I
was biased, but I think it was blamelessly.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
It is the same sort of thing, as
for the son of an admiral to go into the navy, or the son of a general
to be in the army, and nobody sees anything wrong in that. Nobody
wonders that they should prefer the line where their friends can serve
them best, or suspects them to be less in earnest in it than they
appear.
subQuotationList:
['It is the same sort of thing,', 'as
for the son of an admiral to go into the navy, or the son of a general
to be in the army, and nobody sees anything wrong in that. Nobody
wonders that they should prefer the line where their friends can serve
them best, or suspects them to be less in earnest in it than they
appear.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
No, my dear Miss Price, and for reasons good. The profession, either
navy or army, is its own justification. It has everything in its
favour: heroism, danger, bustle, fashion. Soldiers and sailors are
always acceptable in society. Nobody can wonder that men are soldiers
and sailors.
subQuotationList:
['No, my dear Miss Price, and for reasons good. The profession, either
navy or army, is its own justification. It has everything in its
favour: heroism, danger, bustle, fashion. Soldiers and sailors are
always acceptable in society. Nobody can wonder that men are soldiers
and sailors.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
But the motives of a man who takes orders with the certainty of
preferment may be fairly suspected, you think? To be
justified in your eyes, he must do it in the most complete uncertainty
of any provision.
subQuotationList:
['But the motives of a man who takes orders with the certainty of
preferment may be fairly suspected, you think?', 'To be
justified in your eyes, he must do it in the most complete uncertainty
of any provision.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
What! take orders without a living! No; that is madness indeed;
absolute madness.
subQuotationList: ['What! take orders without a living! No; that is madness indeed;\nabsolute madness.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Shall I ask you how the church is to be filled, if a man is neither to
take orders with a living nor without? No; for you certainly would not
know what to say. But I must beg some advantage to the clergyman from
your own argument. As he cannot be influenced by those feelings which
you rank highly as temptation and reward to the soldier and sailor in
their choice of a profession, as heroism, and noise, and fashion, are
all against him, he ought to be less liable to the suspicion of wanting
sincerity or good intentions in the choice of his.
subQuotationList:
['Shall I ask you how the church is to be filled, if a man is neither to
take orders with a living nor without? No; for you certainly would not
know what to say. But I must beg some advantage to the clergyman from
your own argument. As he cannot be influenced by those feelings which
you rank highly as temptation and reward to the soldier and sailor in
their choice of a profession, as heroism, and noise, and fashion, are
all against him, he ought to be less liable to the suspicion of wanting
sincerity or good intentions in the choice of his.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Oh! no doubt he is very sincere in preferring an income ready made, to
the trouble of working for one; and has the best intentions of doing
nothing all the rest of his days but eat, drink, and grow fat. It is
indolence, Mr. Bertram, indeed. Indolence and love of ease; a want of
all laudable ambition, of taste for good company, or of inclination to
take the trouble of being agreeable, which make men clergymen. A
clergyman has nothing to do but be slovenly and selfish   read the
newspaper, watch the weather, and quarrel with his wife. His curate
does all the work, and the business of his own life is to dine.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! no doubt he is very sincere in preferring an income ready made, to
the trouble of working for one; and has the best intentions of doing
nothing all the rest of his days but eat, drink, and grow fat. It is
indolence, Mr. Bertram, indeed. Indolence and love of ease; a want of
all laudable ambition, of taste for good company, or of inclination to
take the trouble of being agreeable, which make men clergymen. A
clergyman has nothing to do but be slovenly and selfish   read the
newspaper, watch the weather, and quarrel with his wife. His curate
does all the work, and the business of his own life is to dine.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
There are such clergymen, no doubt, but I think they are not so common
as to justify Miss Crawford in esteeming it their general character. I
suspect that in this comprehensive and (may I say) commonplace censure,
you are not judging from yourself, but from prejudiced persons, whose
opinions you have been in the habit of hearing. It is impossible that
your own observation can have given you much knowledge of the clergy.
You can have been personally acquainted with very few of a set of men
you condemn so conclusively. You are speaking what you have been told
at your uncle's table.
subQuotationList:
["There are such clergymen, no doubt, but I think they are not so common
as to justify Miss Crawford in esteeming it their general character. I
suspect that in this comprehensive and (may I say) commonplace censure,
you are not judging from yourself, but from prejudiced persons, whose
opinions you have been in the habit of hearing. It is impossible that
your own observation can have given you much knowledge of the clergy.
You can have been personally acquainted with very few of a set of men
you condemn so conclusively. You are speaking what you have been told
at your uncle's table."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I speak what appears to me the general opinion; and where an opinion
is general, it is usually correct. Though _I_ have not seen much of the
domestic lives of clergymen, it is seen by too many to leave any
deficiency of information.
subQuotationList:
['I speak what appears to me the general opinion; and where an opinion
is general, it is usually correct. Though _I_ have not seen much of the
domestic lives of clergymen, it is seen by too many to leave any
deficiency of information.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Where any one body of educated men, of whatever denomination, are
condemned indiscriminately, there must be a deficiency of information,
or (smiling) of something else. Your uncle, and his brother admirals,
perhaps knew little of clergymen beyond the chaplains whom, good or
bad, they were always wishing away.
subQuotationList:
['Where any one body of educated men, of whatever denomination, are
condemned indiscriminately, there must be a deficiency of information,
or (smiling) of something else. Your uncle, and his brother admirals,
perhaps knew little of clergymen beyond the chaplains whom, good or
bad, they were always wishing away.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Poor William! He has met with great kindness from the chaplain of the
Antwerp,
subQuotationList: ['Poor William! He has met with great kindness from the chaplain of the\nAntwerp,']
speaker: Fanny Price
referringExpression: was a tender apostrophe of Fannys

quoteText:
I have been so little addicted to take my opinions from my uncle, that I can hardly suppose   and since you push me so
hard, I must observe, that I am not entirely without the means of
seeing what clergymen are, being at this present time the guest of my
own brother, Dr. Grant. And though Dr. Grant is most kind and obliging
to me, and though he is really a gentleman, and, I dare say, a good
scholar and clever, and often preaches good sermons, and is very
respectable, _I_ see him to be an indolent, selfish _bon_ _vivant_, who
must have his palate consulted in everything; who will not stir a
finger for the convenience of any one; and who, moreover, if the cook
makes a blunder, is out of humour with his excellent wife. To own the
truth, Henry and I were partly driven out this very evening by a
disappointment about a green goose, which he could not get the better
of. My poor sister was forced to stay and bear it.
subQuotationList:
['I have been so little addicted to take my opinions from my uncle,', 'that I can hardly suppose   and since you push me so
hard, I must observe, that I am not entirely without the means of
seeing what clergymen are, being at this present time the guest of my
own brother, Dr. Grant. And though Dr. Grant is most kind and obliging
to me, and though he is really a gentleman, and, I dare say, a good

respectable, _I_ see him to be an indolent, selfish _bon_ _vivant_, who
must have his palate consulted in everything; who will not stir a
finger for the convenience of any one; and who, moreover, if the cook
makes a blunder, is out of humour with his excellent wife. To own the
truth, Henry and I were partly driven out this very evening by a
disappointment about a green goose, which he could not get the better
of. My poor sister was forced to stay and bear it.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionTextsList: [[], ['you', 'my\nown brother', 'Dr. Grant', 'Dr. Grant', 'he', 'him', 'his', 'his excellent wife', 'Henry', 'My poor sister']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Edmund'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Mrs. Grant'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Mrs. Grant']]]

quoteText:
I do not wonder at your disapprobation, upon my word. It is a great
defect of temper, made worse by a very faulty habit of self-indulgence;
and to see your sister suffering from it must be exceedingly painful to
such feelings as yours. Fanny, it goes against us. We cannot attempt to
defend Dr. Grant.
subQuotationList:
['I do not wonder at your disapprobation, upon my word. It is a great
defect of temper, made worse by a very faulty habit of self-indulgence;
and to see your sister suffering from it must be exceedingly painful to
such feelings as yours. Fanny, it goes against us. We cannot attempt to
defend Dr. Grant.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Crawford'], ['Mrs. Grant'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Edmund'], ['Dr. Grant']]]

quoteText:
No, but we need not give up his profession for all
that; because, whatever profession Dr. Grant had chosen, he would have
taken a   not a good temper into it; and as he must, either in the navy
or army, have had a great many more people under his command than he
has now, I think more would have been made unhappy by him as a sailor
or soldier than as a clergyman. Besides, I cannot but suppose that
whatever there may be to wish otherwise in Dr. Grant would have been in
a greater danger of becoming worse in a more active and worldly
profession, where he would have had less time and obligation   where he
might have escaped that knowledge of himself, the _frequency_, at
least, of that knowledge which it is impossible he should escape as he
is now. A man   a sensible man like Dr. Grant, cannot be in the habit of
teaching others their duty every week, cannot go to church twice every
Sunday, and preach such very good sermons in so good a manner as he
does, without being the better for it himself. It must make him think;
and I have no doubt that he oftener endeavours to restrain himself than
he would if he had been anything but a clergyman.
subQuotationList:
['No,', 'but we need not give up his profession for all
that; because, whatever profession Dr. Grant had chosen, he would have
taken a   not a good temper into it; and as he must, either in the navy

he would if he had been anything but a clergyman.']
speaker: Fanny Price
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Fanny Price', 'Edmund'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant']]]

quoteText:
We cannot prove to the contrary, to be sure; but I wish you a better
fate, Miss Price, than to be the wife of a man whose amiableness
depends upon his own sermons; for though he may preach himself into a
good-humour every Sunday, it will be bad enough to have him quarrelling
about green geese from Monday morning till Saturday night.
subQuotationList:
['We cannot prove to the contrary, to be sure; but I wish you a better
fate, Miss Price, than to be the wife of a man whose amiableness
depends upon his own sermons; for though he may preach himself into a
good-humour every Sunday, it will be bad enough to have him quarrelling
about green geese from Monday morning till Saturday night.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: I think the man who could often quarrel with Fanny, must be beyond the reach of any sermons.
subQuotationList: ['I think the man who could often quarrel with Fanny,', 'must be beyond the reach of any sermons.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I fancy Miss Price has been more used to
deserve praise than to hear it
subQuotationList: ['I fancy Miss Price has been more used to\ndeserve praise than to hear it']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: Miss Crawford had only time to say

quoteText: There goes good-humour, I am sure,
subQuotationList: ['There goes good-humour, I am sure,']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
There goes a
temper which would never give pain! How well she walks! and how readily
she falls in with the inclination of others! joining them the moment
she is asked. What a pity, that she should have been in such hands!
subQuotationList:
['There goes a
temper which would never give pain! How well she walks! and how readily
she falls in with the inclination of others! joining them the moment
she is asked. What a pity,', 'that she should have been in such hands!']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Here's harmony! here's repose! Here's
what may leave all painting and all music behind, and what poetry only
can attempt to describe! Here's what may tranquillise every care, and
lift the heart to rapture! When I look out on such a night as this, I
feel as if there could be neither wickedness nor sorrow in the world;
and there certainly would be less of both if the sublimity of Nature
were more attended to, and people were carried more out of themselves
by contemplating such a scene.
subQuotationList:
["Here's harmony!", "here's repose! Here's
what may leave all painting and all music behind, and what poetry only
can attempt to describe! Here's what may tranquillise every care, and
lift the heart to rapture! When I look out on such a night as this, I
feel as if there could be neither wickedness nor sorrow in the world;
and there certainly would be less of both if the sublimity of Nature
were more attended to, and people were carried more out of themselves
by contemplating such a scene."]
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
I like to hear your enthusiasm, Fanny. It is a lovely night, and they
are much to be pitied who have not been taught to feel, in some degree,
as you do; who have not, at least, been given a taste for Nature in
early life. They lose a great deal.
subQuotationList:
['I like to hear your enthusiasm, Fanny. It is a lovely night, and they
are much to be pitied who have not been taught to feel, in some degree,
as you do; who have not, at least, been given a taste for Nature in
early life. They lose a great deal.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: _You_ taught me to think and feel on the subject, cousin.
subQuotationList: ['_You_ taught me to think and feel on the subject, cousin.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: I had a very apt scholar. There's Arcturus looking very bright.
subQuotationList: ["I had a very apt scholar. There's Arcturus looking very bright."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: Yes, and the Bear. I wish I could see Cassiopeia.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, and the Bear. I wish I could see Cassiopeia.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: We must go out on the lawn for that. Should you be afraid?
subQuotationList: ['We must go out on the lawn for that. Should you be afraid?']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Not in the least. It is a great while since we have had any
star-gazing.
subQuotationList: ['Not in the least. It is a great while since we have had any\nstar-gazing.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: Yes; I do not know how it has happened.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; I do not know how it has happened.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
We will stay
till this is finished, Fanny,
subQuotationList: ['We will stay\ntill this is finished, Fanny,']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I am rather
surprised, that Mr. Crawford should come back again so
soon, after being here so long before, full seven weeks; for I had
understood he was so very fond of change and moving about, that I
thought something would certainly occur, when he was once gone, to take
him elsewhere. He is used to much gayer places than Mansfield.
subQuotationList:
['I am rather
surprised,', 'that Mr. Crawford should come back again so
soon, after being here so long before, full seven weeks; for I had
understood he was so very fond of change and moving about, that I
thought something would certainly occur, when he was once gone, to take
him elsewhere. He is used to much gayer places than Mansfield.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
It is to his credit, and I dare say it gives
his sister pleasure. She does not like his unsettled habits.
subQuotationList: ['It is to his credit,', 'and I dare say it gives\nhis sister pleasure. She does not like his unsettled habits.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: What a favourite he is with my cousins!
subQuotationList: ['What a favourite he is with my cousins!']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Yes, his manners to women are such as must please. Mrs. Grant, I
believe, suspects him of a preference for Julia; I have never seen much
symptom of it, but I wish it may be so. He has no faults but what a
serious attachment would remove.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, his manners to women are such as must please. Mrs. Grant, I
believe, suspects him of a preference for Julia; I have never seen much
symptom of it, but I wish it may be so. He has no faults but what a
serious attachment would remove.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
If Miss Bertram were not engaged, I could
sometimes almost think that he admired her more than Julia.
subQuotationList: ['If Miss Bertram were not engaged,', 'I could\nsometimes almost think that he admired her more than Julia.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Which is, perhaps, more in favour of his liking Julia best, than you,
Fanny, may be aware; for I believe it often happens that a man, before
he has quite made up his own mind, will distinguish the sister or
intimate friend of the woman he is really thinking of more than the
woman herself. Crawford has too much sense to stay here if he found
himself in any danger from Maria; and I am not at all afraid for her,
after such a proof as she has given that her feelings are not strong.
subQuotationList:
['Which is, perhaps, more in favour of his liking Julia best, than you,
Fanny, may be aware; for I believe it often happens that a man, before
he has quite made up his own mind, will distinguish the sister or

after such a proof as she has given that her feelings are not strong.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I think, ma'am, we shall
see some happy faces again now.
subQuotationList: ["I think, ma'am,", 'we shall\nsee some happy faces again now.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText:
Yes, ma'am, indeed, there
will be some satisfaction in looking on _now_, and I think it was
rather a pity they should have been obliged to part. Young folks in
their situation should be excused complying with the common forms. I
wonder my son did not propose it.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, ma'am, indeed,", 'there
will be some satisfaction in looking on _now_, and I think it was
rather a pity they should have been obliged to part. Young folks in
their situation should be excused complying with the common forms. I
wonder my son did not propose it.']
speaker: Mrs. Rushworth

quoteText:
I dare say he did, ma'am. Mr. Rushworth is never remiss. But dear
Maria has such a strict sense of propriety, so much of that true
delicacy which one seldom meets with nowadays, Mrs. Rushworth   that wish
of avoiding particularity! Dear ma'am, only look at her face at this
moment; how different from what it was the two last dances!
subQuotationList:
["I dare say he did, ma'am. Mr. Rushworth is never remiss. But dear
Maria has such a strict sense of propriety, so much of that true
delicacy which one seldom meets with nowadays, Mrs. Rushworth   that wish
of avoiding particularity! Dear ma'am, only look at her face at this
moment; how different from what it was the two last dances!"]
speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
It is quite delightful, ma'am, to see young
people so properly happy, so well suited, and so much the thing! I
cannot but think of dear Sir Thomas's delight. And what do you say,
ma'am, to the chance of another match? Mr. Rushworth has set a good
example, and such things are very catching.
subQuotationList:
["It is quite delightful, ma'am, to see young
people so properly happy, so well suited, and so much the thing! I
cannot but think of dear Sir Thomas's delight. And what do you say,
ma'am, to the chance of another match? Mr. Rushworth has set a good
example, and such things are very catching."]
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText: The couple above, ma'am. Do you see no symptoms there?
subQuotationList: ["The couple above, ma'am. Do you see no symptoms there?"]
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText:
Oh dear! Miss Julia and Mr. Crawford. Yes, indeed, a very pretty
match. What is his property?
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear! Miss Julia and Mr. Crawford. Yes, indeed, a very pretty\nmatch. What is his property?']
speaker: Mrs. Rushworth

quoteText: Four thousand a year.
subQuotationList: ['Four thousand a year.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText:
Very well. Those who have not more must be satisfied with what they
have. Four thousand a year is a pretty estate, and he seems a very
genteel, steady young man, so I hope Miss Julia will be very happy.
subQuotationList: ['Very well. Those who have not more must be satisfied with what they\nhave. Four thousand a year is a pretty estate, and he seems a very\ngenteel, steady young man, so I hope Miss Julia will be very happy.']
speaker: Mrs. Rushworth

quoteText:
It is not a settled thing, ma'am, yet. We only speak of it among
friends. But I have very little doubt it _will_ be. He is growing
extremely particular in his attentions.
subQuotationList: ["It is not a settled thing, ma'am, yet. We only speak of it among\nfriends. But I have very little doubt it _will_ be. He is growing\nextremely particular in his attentions."]
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText:
If you
want to dance, Fanny, I will stand up with you.
subQuotationList: ['If you\nwant to dance, Fanny, I will stand up with you.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
referringExpression: he took a newspaper from the table and looking over it said

quoteText:
I am glad
of it, for I am tired to death. I only wonder how the good
people can keep it up so long. They had need be _all_ in love, to find
any amusement in such folly; and so they are, I fancy. If you look at
them you may see they are so many couple of lovers   all but Yates and
Mrs. Grant   and, between ourselves, she, poor woman, must want a lover
as much as any one of them. A desperate dull life hers must be with the
doctor,
subQuotationList:
['I am glad
of it,', 'for I am tired to death. I only wonder how the good
people can keep it up so long. They had need be _all_ in love, to find

quoteText:
A strange business this in
America, Dr. Grant! What is your opinion? I always come to you to know
what I am to think of public matters.
subQuotationList: ['A strange business this in\nAmerica, Dr. Grant! What is your opinion? I always come to you to know\nwhat I am to think of public matters.']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
My dear Tom, as you are not dancing,
I dare say you will have no objection to join us in a rubber; shall
you?
subQuotationList: ['My dear Tom,', 'as you are not dancing,\nI dare say you will have no objection to join us in a rubber; shall\nyou?']
speaker: Mrs. Norris

quoteText:
We want to make a table for Mrs. Rushworth, you
know. Your mother is quite anxious about it, but cannot very well spare
time to sit down herself, because of her fringe. Now, you and I and Dr.
Grant will just do; and though _we_ play but half-crowns, you know, you
may bet half-guineas with _him_.
subQuotationList:
['We want to make a table for Mrs. Rushworth, you
know. Your mother is quite anxious about it, but cannot very well spare
time to sit down herself, because of her fringe. Now, you and I and Dr.
Grant will just do; and though _we_ play but half-crowns, you know, you
may bet half-guineas with _him_.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris
referringExpression: leaving her seat and coming to him to enforce the proposal added
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Dr. Grant']]]

quoteText:
I should be most happy, it would give me the greatest pleasure; but that I am this
moment going to dance. Come, Fanny, do not be
dawdling any longer, or the dance will be over.
subQuotationList: ['I should be most happy,', 'it would give me the greatest pleasure; but that I am this\nmoment going to dance. Come, Fanny,', 'do not be\ndawdling any longer, or the dance will be over.']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
A pretty modest request upon my word, To want to nail me to a card-table for the next two
hours with herself and Dr. Grant, who are always quarrelling, and that
poking old woman, who knows no more of whist than of algebra. I wish my
good aunt would be a little less busy! And to ask me in such a way too!
without ceremony, before them all, so as to leave me no possibility of
refusing. _That_ is what I dislike most particularly. It raises my
spleen more than anything, to have the pretence of being asked, of
being given a choice, and at the same time addressed in such a way as
to oblige one to do the very thing, whatever it be! If I had not
luckily thought of standing up with you I could not have got out of it.
It is a great deal too bad. But when my aunt has got a fancy in her
head, nothing can stop her.
subQuotationList:
['A pretty modest request upon my word,', 'To want to nail me to a card-table for the next two
hours with herself and Dr. Grant, who are always quarrelling, and that
poking old woman, who knows no more of whist than of algebra. I wish my
good aunt would be a little less busy! And to ask me in such a way too!
without ceremony, before them all, so as to leave me no possibility of
refusing. _That_ is what I dislike most particularly. It raises my
spleen more than anything, to have the pretence of being asked, of
being given a choice, and at the same time addressed in such a way as
to oblige one to do the very thing, whatever it be! If I had not
luckily thought of standing up with you I could not have got out of it.
It is a great deal too bad. But when my aunt has got a fancy in her
head, nothing can stop her.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mrs. Norris'], ['Dr. Grant'], ['Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Rushworth'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Norris']]]

quoteText:
A trifling part, and not at all to my taste,
and such a one as I certainly would not accept again; but I was
determined to make no difficulties. Lord Ravenshaw and the duke had
appropriated the only two characters worth playing before I reached
Ecclesford; and though Lord Ravenshaw offered to resign his to me, it
was impossible to take it, you know. I was sorry for _him_ that he
should have so mistaken his powers, for he was no more equal to the
Baron   a little man with a weak voice, always hoarse after the first ten
minutes. It must have injured the piece materially; but _I_ was
resolved to make no difficulties. Sir Henry thought the duke not equal
to Frederick, but that was because Sir Henry wanted the part himself;
whereas it was certainly in the best hands of the two. I was surprised
to see Sir Henry such a stick. Luckily the strength of the piece did
not depend upon him. Our Agatha was inimitable, and the duke was
thought very great by many. And upon the whole, it would certainly have
gone off wonderfully.
subQuotationList:
['A trifling part,', 'and not at all to my taste,
and such a one as I certainly would not accept again; but I was
determined to make no difficulties. Lord Ravenshaw and the duke had
appropriated the only two characters worth playing before I reached

was impossible to take it, you know. I was sorry for _him_ that he
should have so mistaken his powers, for he was no more equal to the
Baron   a little man with a weak voice, always hoarse after the first ten
minutes. It must have injured the piece materially; but _I_ was
resolved to make no difficulties. Sir Henry thought the duke not equal
