to see Sir Henry such a stick. Luckily the strength of the piece did
not depend upon him. Our Agatha was inimitable, and the duke was
thought very great by many. And upon the whole, it would certainly have
gone off wonderfully.']
speaker: Mr. Yates

quoteText: It was a hard case, upon my word
subQuotationList: ['It was a hard case, upon my word']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mr. Yates']

quoteText:
I do think you were very much
to be pitied,
subQuotationList: ['I do think you were very much\nto be pitied,']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mr. Yates']

quoteText:
It is not worth complaining about; but to be sure the poor old dowager
could not have died at a worse time; and it is impossible to help
wishing that the news could have been suppressed for just the three
days we wanted. It was but three days; and being only a grandmother,
and all happening two hundred miles off, I think there would have been
no great harm, and it was suggested, I know; but Lord Ravenshaw, who I
suppose is one of the most correct men in England, would not hear of
it.
subQuotationList:
['It is not worth complaining about; but to be sure the poor old dowager
could not have died at a worse time; and it is impossible to help
wishing that the news could have been suppressed for just the three
days we wanted. It was but three days; and being only a grandmother,
and all happening two hundred miles off, I think there would have been
no great harm, and it was suggested, I know; but Lord Ravenshaw, who I
suppose is one of the most correct men in England, would not hear of
it.']
speaker: Mr. Yates

quoteText:
An afterpiece instead of a comedy, Lovers' Vows
were at an end, and Lord and Lady Ravenshaw left to act My Grandmother
by themselves. Well, the jointure may comfort _him_; and perhaps,
between friends, he began to tremble for his credit and his lungs in
the Baron, and was not sorry to withdraw; and to make _you_ amends,
Yates, I think we must raise a little theatre at Mansfield, and ask you
to be our manager.
subQuotationList:
['An afterpiece instead of a comedy,', "Lovers' Vows
were at an end, and Lord and Lady Ravenshaw left to act My Grandmother
by themselves. Well, the jointure may comfort _him_; and perhaps,
between friends, he began to tremble for his credit and his lungs in
the Baron, and was not sorry to withdraw; and to make _you_ amends,
Yates, I think we must raise a little theatre at Mansfield, and ask you
to be our manager."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Yates'], ['Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram'], ['Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
Oh for
the Ecclesford theatre and scenery to try something with.
subQuotationList: ['Oh for\nthe Ecclesford theatre and scenery to try something with.']
speaker: Mr. Yates

quoteText:
I really believe, I could be fool enough at this
moment to undertake any character that ever was written, from Shylock
or Richard III down to the singing hero of a farce in his scarlet coat
and cocked hat. I feel as if I could be anything or everything; as if I
could rant and storm, or sigh or cut capers, in any tragedy or comedy
in the English language. Let us be doing something. Be it only half a
play, an act, a scene; what should prevent us? Not these countenances,
I am sure, and for a theatre, what
signifies a theatre? We shall be only amusing ourselves. Any room in
this house might suffice.
subQuotationList:
['I really believe,', 'I could be fool enough at this
moment to undertake any character that ever was written, from Shylock
or Richard III down to the singing hero of a farce in his scarlet coat
and cocked hat. I feel as if I could be anything or everything; as if I
could rant and storm, or sigh or cut capers, in any tragedy or comedy
in the English language. Let us be doing something. Be it only half a
play, an act, a scene; what should prevent us? Not these countenances,
I am sure,', 'and for a theatre, what
signifies a theatre? We shall be only amusing ourselves. Any room in
this house might suffice.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']], [['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
We must have a curtain, a few yards of green baize
for a curtain, and perhaps that may be enough.
subQuotationList: ['We must have a curtain,', 'a few yards of green baize\nfor a curtain, and perhaps that may be enough.']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
Oh, quite enough, with only just a side wing or two
run up, doors in flat, and three or four scenes to be let down; nothing
more would be necessary on such a plan as this. For mere amusement
among ourselves we should want nothing more.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, quite enough,', 'with only just a side wing or two
run up, doors in flat, and three or four scenes to be let down; nothing
more would be necessary on such a plan as this. For mere amusement
among ourselves we should want nothing more.']
speaker: Mr. Yates

quoteText:
I believe we must be satisfied with _less_, There would
not be time, and other difficulties would arise. We must rather adopt
Mr. Crawford's views, and make the _performance_, not the _theatre_,
our object. Many parts of our best plays are independent of scenery.
subQuotationList:
['I believe we must be satisfied with _less_,', "There would
not be time, and other difficulties would arise. We must rather adopt
Mr. Crawford's views, and make the _performance_, not the _theatre_,
our object. Many parts of our best plays are independent of scenery."]
speaker: Maria Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']], [['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
Nay, Let us do nothing
by halves. If we are to act, let it be in a theatre completely fitted
up with pit, boxes, and gallery, and let us have a play entire from
beginning to end; so as it be a German play, no matter what, with a
good tricking, shifting afterpiece, and a figure-dance, and a hornpipe,
and a song between the acts. If we do not outdo Ecclesford, we do
nothing.
subQuotationList:
['Nay,', 'Let us do nothing
by halves. If we are to act, let it be in a theatre completely fitted
up with pit, boxes, and gallery, and let us have a play entire from

and a song between the acts. If we do not outdo Ecclesford, we do

speaker: Edmund
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
Now, Edmund, do not be disagreeable, Nobody loves a play
better than you do, or can have gone much farther to see one.
subQuotationList: ['Now, Edmund, do not be disagreeable,', 'Nobody loves a play\nbetter than you do, or can have gone much farther to see one.']
speaker: Julia Bertram

quoteText:
True, to see real acting, good hardened real acting; but I would
hardly walk from this room to the next to look at the raw efforts of
those who have not been bred to the trade: a set of gentlemen and
ladies, who have all the disadvantages of education and decorum to
struggle through.
subQuotationList:
['True, to see real acting, good hardened real acting; but I would
hardly walk from this room to the next to look at the raw efforts of
those who have not been bred to the trade: a set of gentlemen and
ladies, who have all the disadvantages of education and decorum to
struggle through.']
speaker: Edmund
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']

quoteText:
Such a horribly vile billiard-table as ours
is not to be met with, I believe, above ground. I can stand it no
longer, and I think, I may say, that nothing shall ever tempt me to it
again; but one good thing I have just ascertained: it is the very room
for a theatre, precisely the shape and length for it; and the doors at
the farther end, communicating with each other, as they may be made to
do in five minutes, by merely moving the bookcase in my father's room,
is the very thing we could have desired, if we had sat down to wish for
it; and my father's room will be an excellent greenroom. It seems to
join the billiard-room on purpose.
subQuotationList:
["Such a horribly vile billiard-table as ours
is not to be met with, I believe, above ground. I can stand it no
longer, and I think, I may say, that nothing shall ever tempt me to it
again; but one good thing I have just ascertained: it is the very room

it; and my father's room will be an excellent greenroom. It seems to
join the billiard-room on purpose."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mr. Yates']
referringExpression: Tom returning from them into the drawingroom where Edmund was standing thoughtfully by the fire while Lady Bertram was on the sofa at a little distance and Fanny close beside her arranging her work thus began
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText: You are not serious, Tom, in meaning to act?
subQuotationList: ['You are not serious, Tom, in meaning to act?']
speaker: Edmund
referringExpression: said Edmund in a low voice as his brother approached the fire

quoteText:
Not serious! never more so, I assure you. What is there to surprise
you in it?
subQuotationList: ['Not serious! never more so, I assure you. What is there to surprise\nyou in it?']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
I think it would be very wrong. In a _general_ light, private
theatricals are open to some objections, but as _we_ are circumstanced,
I must think it would be highly injudicious, and more than injudicious
to attempt anything of the kind. It would shew great want of feeling on
my father's account, absent as he is, and in some degree of constant
danger; and it would be imprudent, I think, with regard to Maria, whose
situation is a very delicate one, considering everything, extremely
delicate.
subQuotationList:
["I think it would be very wrong. In a _general_ light, private
theatricals are open to some objections, but as _we_ are circumstanced,
I must think it would be highly injudicious, and more than injudicious
to attempt anything of the kind. It would shew great want of feeling on
my father's account, absent as he is, and in some degree of constant
danger; and it would be imprudent, I think, with regard to Maria, whose
situation is a very delicate one, considering everything, extremely
delicate."]
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
You take up a thing so seriously! as if we were going to act three
times a week till my father's return, and invite all the country. But
it is not to be a display of that sort. We mean nothing but a little
amusement among ourselves, just to vary the scene, and exercise our
powers in something new. We want no audience, no publicity. We may be
trusted, I think, in chusing some play most perfectly unexceptionable;
and I can conceive no greater harm or danger to any of us in conversing
in the elegant written language of some respectable author than in
chattering in words of our own. I have no fears and no scruples. And as
to my father's being absent, it is so far from an objection, that I
consider it rather as a motive; for the expectation of his return must
be a very anxious period to my mother; and if we can be the means of
amusing that anxiety, and keeping up her spirits for the next few
weeks, I shall think our time very well spent, and so, I am sure, will
he. It is a _very_ anxious period for her.
subQuotationList:
["You take up a thing so seriously! as if we were going to act three
times a week till my father's return, and invite all the country. But
it is not to be a display of that sort. We mean nothing but a little

amusing that anxiety, and keeping up her spirits for the next few
weeks, I shall think our time very well spent, and so, I am sure, will
he. It is a _very_ anxious period for her."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edmund'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram']]]

quoteText:
By Jove! this won't do, To be sure, my dear mother, your anxiety   I was unlucky
there.
subQuotationList: ["By Jove! this won't do,", 'To be sure, my dear mother, your anxiety   I was unlucky\nthere.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mr. Yates']

quoteText: What is the matter? I was not asleep.
subQuotationList: ['What is the matter?', 'I was not asleep.']
speaker: Lady Bertram
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mr. Yates']

quoteText: Oh dear, no, ma'am, nobody suspected you! Well, Edmund,
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, no, ma'am, nobody suspected you! Well, Edmund,"]
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mr. Yates']

quoteText:
but _this_ I _will_ maintain, that we
shall be doing no harm.
subQuotationList: ['but _this_ I _will_ maintain, that we\nshall be doing no harm.']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
I cannot agree with you; I am convinced that my father would totally
disapprove it.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot agree with you; I am convinced that my father would totally\ndisapprove it.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
And I am convinced to the contrary. Nobody is fonder of the exercise
of talent in young people, or promotes it more, than my father, and for
anything of the acting, spouting, reciting kind, I think he has always
a decided taste. I am sure he encouraged it in us as boys. How many a
time have we mourned over the dead body of Julius Caesar, and to _be'd_
and not _to_ _be'd_, in this very room, for his amusement? And I am
sure, _my_ _name_ _was_ _Norval_, every evening of my life through one
Christmas holidays.
subQuotationList:
["And I am convinced to the contrary. Nobody is fonder of the exercise
of talent in young people, or promotes it more, than my father, and for
anything of the acting, spouting, reciting kind, I think he has always
a decided taste. I am sure he encouraged it in us as boys. How many a
time have we mourned over the dead body of Julius Caesar, and to _be'd_
and not _to_ _be'd_, in this very room, for his amusement? And I am
sure, _my_ _name_ _was_ _Norval_, every evening of my life through one
Christmas holidays."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
It was a very different thing. You must see the difference yourself.
My father wished us, as schoolboys, to speak well, but he would never
wish his grown-up daughters to be acting plays. His sense of decorum is
strict.
subQuotationList:
['It was a very different thing. You must see the difference yourself.
My father wished us, as schoolboys, to speak well, but he would never
wish his grown-up daughters to be acting plays. His sense of decorum is
strict.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
I know all that, I know my father as well as
you do; and I'll take care that his daughters do nothing to distress
him. Manage your own concerns, Edmund, and I'll take care of the rest
of the family.
subQuotationList:
['I know all that,', "I know my father as well as
you do; and I'll take care that his daughters do nothing to distress
him. Manage your own concerns, Edmund, and I'll take care of the rest
of the family."]
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
If you are resolved on acting, I
must hope it will be in a very small and quiet way; and I think a
theatre ought not to be attempted. It would be taking liberties with my
father's house in his absence which could not be justified.
subQuotationList:
['If you are resolved on acting,', "I
must hope it will be in a very small and quiet way; and I think a
theatre ought not to be attempted. It would be taking liberties with my
father's house in his absence which could not be justified."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
For everything of that nature I will be answerable, His house shall not be hurt. I have quite as great an
interest in being careful of his house as you can have; and as to such
alterations as I was suggesting just now, such as moving a bookcase, or
unlocking a door, or even as using the billiard-room for the space of a
week without playing at billiards in it, you might just as well suppose
he would object to our sitting more in this room, and less in the
breakfast-room, than we did before he went away, or to my sister's
pianoforte being moved from one side of the room to the other. Absolute
nonsense!
subQuotationList:
['For everything of that nature I will be answerable,', "His house shall not be hurt. I have quite as great an
interest in being careful of his house as you can have; and as to such
alterations as I was suggesting just now, such as moving a bookcase, or
unlocking a door, or even as using the billiard-room for the space of a
week without playing at billiards in it, you might just as well suppose
he would object to our sitting more in this room, and less in the
breakfast-room, than we did before he went away, or to my sister's
pianoforte being moved from one side of the room to the other. Absolute
nonsense!"]
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
The innovation, if not wrong as an innovation, will be wrong as an
expense.
subQuotationList: ['The innovation, if not wrong as an innovation, will be wrong as an\nexpense.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Yes, the expense of such an undertaking would be prodigious! Perhaps
it might cost a whole twenty pounds. Something of a theatre we must
have undoubtedly, but it will be on the simplest plan: a green curtain
and a little carpenter's work, and that's all; and as the carpenter's
work may be all done at home by Christopher Jackson himself, it will be
too absurd to talk of expense; and as long as Jackson is employed,
everything will be right with Sir Thomas. Don't imagine that nobody in
this house can see or judge but yourself. Don't act yourself, if you do
not like it, but don't expect to govern everybody else.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, the expense of such an undertaking would be prodigious! Perhaps
it might cost a whole twenty pounds. Something of a theatre we must
have undoubtedly, but it will be on the simplest plan: a green curtain
and a little carpenter's work, and that's all; and as the carpenter's
work may be all done at home by Christopher Jackson himself, it will be
too absurd to talk of expense; and as long as Jackson is employed,
everything will be right with Sir Thomas. Don't imagine that nobody in
this house can see or judge but yourself. Don't act yourself, if you do
not like it, but don't expect to govern everybody else."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText:
No, as to acting myself, _that_ I absolutely protest
against.
subQuotationList: ['No, as to acting myself,', '_that_ I absolutely protest\nagainst.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Perhaps they may not be able to find any play to suit
them. Your brother's taste and your sisters' seem very different.
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps they may not be able to find any play to suit\nthem. Your brother's taste and your sisters' seem very different."]
speaker: Fanny Price
referringExpression: Fanny who had heard it all and borne Edmund company in every feeling throughout the whole now ventured to say
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram']]]

quoteText:
I have no hope there, Fanny. If they persist in the scheme, they will
find something. I shall speak to my sisters and try to dissuade _them_,
and that is all I can do.
subQuotationList: ['I have no hope there, Fanny. If they persist in the scheme, they will\nfind something. I shall speak to my sisters and try to dissuade _them_,\nand that is all I can do.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram']]]

quoteText: I should think my aunt Norris would be on your side.
subQuotationList: ['I should think my aunt Norris would be on your side.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
I dare say she would, but she has no influence with either Tom or my
sisters that could be of any use; and if I cannot convince them myself,
I shall let things take their course, without attempting it through
her. Family squabbling is the greatest evil of all, and we had better
do anything than be altogether by the ears.
subQuotationList:
['I dare say she would, but she has no influence with either Tom or my
sisters that could be of any use; and if I cannot convince them myself,
I shall let things take their course, without attempting it through
her. Family squabbling is the greatest evil of all, and we had better
do anything than be altogether by the ears.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mrs. Norris'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText:
No want of hands in our theatre, Miss
Bertram. No want of understrappers: my sister desires her love, and
hopes to be admitted into the company, and will be happy to take the
part of any old duenna or tame confidante, that you may not like to do
yourselves.
subQuotationList:
['No want of hands in our theatre, Miss
Bertram. No want of understrappers: my sister desires her love, and
hopes to be admitted into the company, and will be happy to take the
part of any old duenna or tame confidante, that you may not like to do
yourselves.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
referringExpression: Henry Crawford entered the room fresh from the Parsonage calling out
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Edmund', 'Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
Oh no, _that_ will never do! Let us
have no ranting tragedies. Too many characters. Not a tolerable woman's
part in the play. Anything but _that_, my dear Tom. It would be
impossible to fill it up. One could not expect anybody to take such a
part. Nothing but buffoonery from beginning to end. _That_ might do,
perhaps, but for the low parts. If I _must_ give my opinion, I have
always thought it the most insipid play in the English language. _I_ do
not wish to make objections; I shall be happy to be of any use, but I
think we could not chuse worse.
subQuotationList:
["Oh no, _that_ will never do! Let us
have no ranting tragedies. Too many characters. Not a tolerable woman's
part in the play. Anything but _that_, my dear Tom. It would be

part. Nothing but buffoonery from beginning to end. _That_ might do,

not wish to make objections; I shall be happy to be of any use, but I
think we could not chuse worse."]
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
This will never do, We are wasting time
most abominably. Something must be fixed on. No matter what, so that
something is chosen. We must not be so nice. A few characters too many
must not frighten us. We must _double_ them. We must descend a little.
If a part is insignificant, the greater our credit in making anything
of it. From this moment I make no difficulties. I take any part you
chuse to give me, so as it be comic. Let it but be comic, I condition
for nothing more.
subQuotationList:
['This will never do,', 'We are wasting time
most abominably. Something must be fixed on. No matter what, so that
something is chosen. We must not be so nice. A few characters too many

If a part is insignificant, the greater our credit in making anything
of it. From this moment I make no difficulties. I take any part you
chuse to give me, so as it be comic. Let it but be comic, I condition

speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
Lovers' Vows! And
why should not Lovers' Vows do for _us_ as well as for the Ravenshaws?
How came it never to be thought of before? It strikes me as if it would
do exactly. What say you all? Here are two capital tragic parts for
Yates and Crawford, and here is the rhyming Butler for me, if nobody
else wants it; a trifling part, but the sort of thing I should not
dislike, and, as I said before, I am determined to take anything and do
my best. And as for the rest, they may be filled up by anybody. It is
only Count Cassel and Anhalt.
subQuotationList:
["Lovers' Vows! And
why should not Lovers' Vows do for _us_ as well as for the Ravenshaws?
How came it never to be thought of before? It strikes me as if it would
do exactly. What say you all? Here are two capital tragic parts for
Yates and Crawford, and here is the rhyming Butler for me, if nobody
else wants it; a trifling part, but the sort of thing I should not
dislike, and, as I said before, I am determined to take anything and do
my best. And as for the rest, they may be filled up by anybody. It is
only Count Cassel and Anhalt."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']
referringExpression: the same speaker who taking up one of the many volumes of plays that lay on the table and turning it over suddenly exclaimed
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
This is not behaving well by the absent, Here are not
women enough. Amelia and Agatha may do for Maria and me, but here is
nothing for your sister, Mr. Crawford.
subQuotationList: ['This is not behaving well by the absent,', 'Here are not\nwomen enough. Amelia and Agatha may do for Maria and me, but here is\nnothing for your sister, Mr. Crawford.']
speaker: Julia Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']

quoteText:
It falls as naturally, as necessarily to her, as Agatha does to one or other of my sisters. It can be no
sacrifice on their side, for it is highly comic.
subQuotationList: ['It falls as naturally, as necessarily to her,', 'as Agatha does to one or other of my sisters. It can be no\nsacrifice on their side, for it is highly comic.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']

quoteText:
I must entreat Miss _Julia_ Bertram, not to engage in the
part of Agatha, or it will be the ruin of all my solemnity. You must
not, indeed you must not I could not stand your
countenance dressed up in woe and paleness. The many laughs we have had
together would infallibly come across me, and Frederick and his
knapsack would be obliged to run away.
subQuotationList:
['I must entreat Miss _Julia_ Bertram,', 'not to engage in the
part of Agatha, or it will be the ruin of all my solemnity. You must
not, indeed you must not', 'I could not stand your
countenance dressed up in woe and paleness. The many laughs we have had
together would infallibly come across me, and Frederick and his
knapsack would be obliged to run away.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Julia Bertram']], [['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram']], [['Julia Bertram'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Julia Bertram']]]

quoteText:
Oh yes! Maria must be Agatha. Maria will be the
best Agatha. Though Julia fancies she prefers tragedy, I would not
trust her in it. There is nothing of tragedy about her. She has not the
look of it. Her features are not tragic features, and she walks too
quick, and speaks too quick, and would not keep her countenance. She
had better do the old countrywoman: the Cottager's wife; you had,
indeed, Julia. Cottager's wife is a very pretty part, I assure you. The
old lady relieves the high-flown benevolence of her husband with a good
deal of spirit. You shall be Cottager's wife.
subQuotationList:
["Oh yes! Maria must be Agatha. Maria will be the
best Agatha. Though Julia fancies she prefers tragedy, I would not
trust her in it. There is nothing of tragedy about her. She has not the

speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']
referringExpression: her brother gave his weight against her too by saying
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram']]]

quoteText:
Cottager's wife! What are you talking of? The most
trivial, paltry, insignificant part; the merest commonplace; not a
tolerable speech in the whole. Your sister do that! It is an insult to
propose it. At Ecclesford the governess was to have done it. We all
agreed that it could not be offered to anybody else. A little more
justice, Mr. Manager, if you please. You do not deserve the office, if
you cannot appreciate the talents of your company a little better.
subQuotationList:
["Cottager's wife!", 'What are you talking of? The most
trivial, paltry, insignificant part; the merest commonplace; not a
tolerable speech in the whole. Your sister do that! It is an insult to
propose it. At Ecclesford the governess was to have done it. We all
agreed that it could not be offered to anybody else. A little more
justice, Mr. Manager, if you please. You do not deserve the office, if
you cannot appreciate the talents of your company a little better.']
speaker: Mr. Yates
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Tom Bertram'], ['Mr. Yates'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram']]]

quoteText:
Why, as to _that_, my good friend, till I and my company have really
acted there must be some guesswork; but I mean no disparagement to
Julia. We cannot have two Agathas, and we must have one Cottager's
wife; and I am sure I set her the example of moderation myself in being
satisfied with the old Butler. If the part is trifling she will have
more credit in making something of it; and if she is so desperately
bent against everything humorous, let her take Cottager's speeches
instead of Cottager's wife's, and so change the parts all through; _he_
is solemn and pathetic enough, I am sure. It could make no difference
in the play, and as for Cottager himself, when he has got his wife's
speeches, _I_ would undertake him with all my heart.
subQuotationList:
["Why, as to _that_, my good friend, till I and my company have really
acted there must be some guesswork; but I mean no disparagement to

more credit in making something of it; and if she is so desperately
bent against everything humorous, let her take Cottager's speeches
instead of Cottager's wife's, and so change the parts all through; _he_
is solemn and pathetic enough, I am sure. It could make no difference
in the play, and as for Cottager himself, when he has got his wife's
speeches, _I_ would undertake him with all my heart."]

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Yates'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
With all your partiality for Cottager's wife, it will be impossible to make anything of it fit for your sister, and
we must not suffer her good-nature to be imposed on. We must not
_allow_ her to accept the part. She must not be left to her own
complaisance. Her talents will be wanted in Amelia. Amelia is a
character more difficult to be well represented than even Agatha. I
consider Amelia is the most difficult character in the whole piece. It
requires great powers, great nicety, to give her playfulness and
simplicity without extravagance. I have seen good actresses fail in the
part. Simplicity, indeed, is beyond the reach of almost every actress
by profession. It requires a delicacy of feeling which they have not.
It requires a gentlewoman   a Julia Bertram. You _will_ undertake it, I
hope?

by profession. It requires a delicacy of feeling which they have not.

hope?']

quoteText:
No, no, Julia must not be Amelia. It is not at all the part for her.
She would not like it. She would not do well. She is too tall and
robust. Amelia should be a small, light, girlish, skipping figure. It
is fit for Miss Crawford, and Miss Crawford only. She looks the part,
and I am persuaded will do it admirably.

quoteText:
You must oblige us, indeed you must. When you have studied
the character, I am sure you will feel it suit you. Tragedy may be your
choice, but it will certainly appear that comedy chuses _you_. You will
be to visit me in prison with a basket of provisions; you will not
refuse to visit me in prison? I think I see you coming in with your
basket.

quoteText: Miss Crawford must be Amelia. She will be an excellent Amelia.

speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']

quoteText:
Do not be afraid of _my_ wanting the character, I am _not_ to be Agatha, and I am sure I will do
nothing else; and as to Amelia, it is of all parts in the world the
most disgusting to me. I quite detest her. An odious, little, pert,
unnatural, impudent girl. I have always protested against comedy, and
this is comedy in its worst form.

unnatural, impudent girl. I have always protested against comedy, and
this is comedy in its worst form.']

quoteText:
We have got a play, It is to be Lovers' Vows; and I am to
be Count Cassel, and am to come in first with a blue dress and a pink
satin cloak, and afterwards am to have another fine fancy suit, by way
of a shooting-dress. I do not know how I shall like it.
subQuotationList:

be Count Cassel, and am to come in first with a blue dress and a pink
satin cloak, and afterwards am to have another fine fancy suit, by way
of a shooting-dress. I do not know how I shall like it."]
speaker: Mr. Rushworth
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']], []]

quoteText: Lovers' Vows!
subQuotationList: ["Lovers' Vows!"]
speaker: Edmund
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris']
referringExpression: was his only reply to Mr Rushworth

quoteText:
Yes, After all our debatings and difficulties, we
find there is nothing that will suit us altogether so well, nothing so
unexceptionable, as Lovers' Vows. The wonder is that it should not have
been thought of before. My stupidity was abominable, for here we have
all the advantage of what I saw at Ecclesford; and it is so useful to
have anything of a model! We have cast almost every part.

all the advantage of what I saw at Ecclesford; and it is so useful to
have anything of a model! We have cast almost every part."]

I should not have thought it the sort of play to be so easily filled
up, with _us_,

quoteText:
I come in three times, and have
two-and-forty speeches. That's something, is not it? But I do not much
like the idea of being so fine. I shall hardly know myself in a blue
dress and a pink satin cloak.
subQuotationList:
["I come in three times, and have
two-and-forty speeches. That's something, is not it? But I do not much
like the idea of being so fine. I shall hardly know myself in a blue
dress and a pink satin cloak."]
speaker: Mr. Rushworth
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris']
referringExpression: Mr Rushworth followed him to say

quoteText:
I
cannot, before Mr. Yates, speak what I feel as to this play, without
reflecting on his friends at Ecclesford; but I must now, my dear Maria,
tell _you_, that I think it exceedingly unfit for private
representation, and that I hope you will give it up. I cannot but
suppose you _will_ when you have read it carefully over. Read only the
first act aloud to either your mother or aunt, and see how you can
approve it. It will not be necessary to send you to your _father's_
judgment, I am convinced.
subQuotationList:
["I
cannot, before Mr. Yates, speak what I feel as to this play, without

tell _you_, that I think it exceedingly unfit for private
representation, and that I hope you will give it up. I cannot but
suppose you _will_ when you have read it carefully over. Read only the
first act aloud to either your mother or aunt, and see how you can
approve it. It will not be necessary to send you to your _father's_
judgment, I am convinced."]
speaker: Edmund
referringExpression: Edmund almost immediately took the opportunity of saying

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Yates'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
We see things very differently, I am perfectly
acquainted with the play, I assure you; and with a very few omissions,
and so forth, which will be made, of course, I can see nothing
objectionable in it; and _I_ am not the _only_ young woman you find who
thinks it very fit for private representation.
subQuotationList:

acquainted with the play, I assure you; and with a very few omissions,
and so forth, which will be made, of course, I can see nothing
objectionable in it; and _I_ am not the _only_ young woman you find who
thinks it very fit for private representation.']
speaker: Maria Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']], []]

quoteText:
I am sorry for it, but in this matter it is _you_
who are to lead. _You_ must set the example. If others have blundered,
it is your place to put them right, and shew them what true delicacy
is. In all points of decorum _your_ conduct must be law to the rest of
the party.
subQuotationList:
['I am sorry for it,', 'but in this matter it is _you_
who are to lead. _You_ must set the example. If others have blundered,
it is your place to put them right, and shew them what true delicacy
is. In all points of decorum _your_ conduct must be law to the rest of
the party.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I am much obliged to you, Edmund; you mean very well, I am sure: but I
still think you see things too strongly; and I really cannot undertake
to harangue all the rest upon a subject of this kind. _There_ would be
the greatest indecorum, I think.
subQuotationList:
['I am much obliged to you, Edmund; you mean very well, I am sure: but I
still think you see things too strongly; and I really cannot undertake
to harangue all the rest upon a subject of this kind. _There_ would be
the greatest indecorum, I think.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText:
Do you imagine that I could have such an idea in my head? No; let your
conduct be the only harangue. Say that, on examining the part, you feel
yourself unequal to it; that you find it requiring more exertion and
confidence than you can be supposed to have. Say this with firmness,
and it will be quite enough. All who can distinguish will understand
your motive. The play will be given up, and your delicacy honoured as
it ought.
subQuotationList:
['Do you imagine that I could have such an idea in my head? No; let your
conduct be the only harangue. Say that, on examining the part, you feel
yourself unequal to it; that you find it requiring more exertion and
confidence than you can be supposed to have. Say this with firmness,
and it will be quite enough. All who can distinguish will understand
your motive. The play will be given up, and your delicacy honoured as
it ought.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
Do not act anything improper, my dear, Sir Thomas
would not like it.   Fanny, ring the bell; I must have my dinner.   To be
sure, Julia is dressed by this time.
subQuotationList: ['Do not act anything improper, my dear,', 'Sir Thomas\nwould not like it.   Fanny, ring the bell; I must have my dinner.   To be\nsure, Julia is dressed by this time.']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
I am convinced, madam, that Sir
Thomas would not like it.
subQuotationList: ['I am convinced, madam,', 'that Sir\nThomas would not like it.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: There, my dear, do you hear what Edmund says?
subQuotationList: ['There, my dear, do you hear what Edmund says?']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
If I were to decline the part, Julia
would certainly take it.
subQuotationList: ['If I were to decline the part,', 'Julia\nwould certainly take it.']
speaker: Maria Bertram

quoteText: What! if she knew your reasons!
subQuotationList: ['What!', 'if she knew your reasons!']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Oh! she might think the difference between us   the difference in our
situations   that _she_ need not be so scrupulous as _I_ might feel
necessary. I am sure she would argue so. No; you must excuse me; I
cannot retract my consent; it is too far settled, everybody would be so
disappointed, Tom would be quite angry; and if we are so very nice, we
shall never act anything.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! she might think the difference between us   the difference in our
situations   that _she_ need not be so scrupulous as _I_ might feel
necessary. I am sure she would argue so. No; you must excuse me; I
cannot retract my consent; it is too far settled, everybody would be so
disappointed, Tom would be quite angry; and if we are so very nice, we
shall never act anything.']
speaker: Maria Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Julia Bertram'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Edmund'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram']]]

quoteText:
I was just going to say the very same thing, If
every play is to be objected to, you will act nothing, and the
preparations will be all so much money thrown away, and I am sure
_that_ would be a discredit to us all. I do not know the play; but, as
Maria says, if there is anything a little too warm (and it is so with
most of them) it can be easily left out. We must not be over-precise,
Edmund. As Mr. Rushworth is to act too, there can be no harm. I only
wish Tom had known his own mind when the carpenters began, for there
was the loss of half a day's work about those side-doors. The curtain
will be a good job, however. The maids do their work very well, and I
think we shall be able to send back some dozens of the rings. There is
no occasion to put them so very close together. I _am_ of some use, I
hope, in preventing waste and making the most of things. There should
always be one steady head to superintend so many young ones. I forgot
to tell Tom of something that happened to me this very day. I had been
looking about me in the poultry-yard, and was just coming out, when who
should I see but Dick Jackson making up to the servants' hall-door with
two bits of deal board in his hand, bringing them to father, you may be
sure; mother had chanced to send him of a message to father, and then
father had bid him bring up them two bits of board, for he could not no
how do without them. I knew what all this meant, for the servants'
dinner-bell was ringing at the very moment over our heads; and as I
hate such encroaching people (the Jacksons are very encroaching, I have
always said so: just the sort of people to get all they can), I said to
the boy directly (a great lubberly fellow of ten years old, you know,
who ought to be ashamed of himself),    _I'll_ take the boards to your
father, Dick, so get you home again as fast as you can.' The boy looked
very silly, and turned away without offering a word, for I believe I
might speak pretty sharp; and I dare say it will cure him of coming
marauding about the house for one while. I hate such greediness   so good
as your father is to the family, employing the man all the year round!
subQuotationList:
['I was just going to say the very same thing,', "If

might speak pretty sharp; and I dare say it will cure him of coming

as your father is to the family, employing the man all the year round!"]
speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Mrs. Norris', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText: Well, how do you go on?
subQuotationList: ['Well, how do you go on?']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText: What have you settled?
subQuotationList: ['What have you settled?']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
Oh! we can
do nothing without you,
subQuotationList: ['Oh! we can\ndo nothing without you,']
speaker: _unknowable

quoteText:
I must really congratulate your ladyship, on the play being chosen; for though you have borne it with
exemplary patience, I am sure you must be sick of all our noise and
difficulties. The actors may be glad, but the bystanders must be
infinitely more thankful for a decision; and I do sincerely give you
joy, madam, as well as Mrs. Norris, and everybody else who is in the
same predicament,
subQuotationList:
['I must really congratulate your ladyship,', 'on the play being chosen; for though you have borne it with
exemplary patience, I am sure you must be sick of all our noise and
difficulties. The actors may be glad, but the bystanders must be
infinitely more thankful for a decision; and I do sincerely give you
joy, madam, as well as Mrs. Norris, and everybody else who is in the
same predicament,']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Bertram']], [['Lady Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Edmund', 'Julia Bertram', 'Lady Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Mrs. Norris']]]

quoteText:
My good friends, you are most composedly
at work upon these cottages and alehouses, inside and out; but pray let
me know my fate in the meanwhile. Who is to be Anhalt? What gentleman
among you am I to have the pleasure of making love to?
subQuotationList:
['My good friends, you are most composedly
at work upon these cottages and alehouses, inside and out; but pray let
me know my fate in the meanwhile. Who is to be Anhalt? What gentleman
among you am I to have the pleasure of making love to?']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']]]

quoteText:
Mr.
Rushworth was to be Count Cassel, but no one had yet undertaken
Anhalt.
subQuotationList: ['Mr.\nRushworth was to be Count Cassel, but no one had yet undertaken\nAnhalt.']
speaker: _unknowable
addressees: ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram']

quoteText:
I had my choice of the parts, but I thought I
should like the Count best, though I do not much relish the finery I am
to have.
subQuotationList: ['I had my choice of the parts,', 'but I thought I\nshould like the Count best, though I do not much relish the finery I am\nto have.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText: You chose very wisely, I am sure, Anhalt is a heavy part.
subQuotationList: ['You chose very wisely, I am sure,', 'Anhalt is a heavy part.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: _The_ _Count_ has two-and-forty speeches, which is no trifle.
subQuotationList: ['_The_ _Count_ has two-and-forty speeches,', 'which is no trifle.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth

quoteText:
I am not at all surprised, at this want of an Anhalt. Amelia deserves no better. Such a forward
young lady may well frighten the men.
subQuotationList: ['I am not at all surprised,', 'at this want of an Anhalt. Amelia deserves no better. Such a forward\nyoung lady may well frighten the men.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
I should be but too happy in taking the part, if it were possible, but, unluckily, the Butler and Anhalt are in together. I
will not entirely give it up, however; I will try what can be done   I
will look it over again.
subQuotationList: ['I should be but too happy in taking the part, if it were possible,', 'but, unluckily, the Butler and Anhalt are in together. I\nwill not entirely give it up, however; I will try what can be done   I\nwill look it over again.']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText: Your _brother_ should take the part, Do not you think he would?
subQuotationList: ['Your _brother_ should take the part,', 'Do not you think he would?']
speaker: Mr. Yates

quoteText: _I_ shall not ask him,
subQuotationList: ['_I_ shall not ask him,']
speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText:
They do not want me at all, I only puzzle
them, and oblige them to make civil speeches. Mr. Edmund Bertram, as
you do not act yourself, you will be a disinterested adviser; and,
therefore, I apply to _you_. What shall we do for an Anhalt? Is it
practicable for any of the others to double it? What is your advice?
subQuotationList:
['They do not want me at all,', 'I only puzzle
them, and oblige them to make civil speeches. Mr. Edmund Bertram, as
you do not act yourself, you will be a disinterested adviser; and,
therefore, I apply to _you_. What shall we do for an Anhalt? Is it
practicable for any of the others to double it? What is your advice?']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates']], [['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText: My advice, is that you change the play.
subQuotationList: ['My advice,', 'is that you change the play.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
_I_ should have no objection, for though I should not
particularly dislike the part of Amelia if well supported, that is, if
everything went well, I shall be sorry to be an inconvenience; but as
they do not chuse to hear your advice at _that_ _table_ it certainly will not be taken.
subQuotationList:
['_I_ should have no objection,', 'for though I should not
particularly dislike the part of Amelia if well supported, that is, if
everything went well, I shall be sorry to be an inconvenience; but as
they do not chuse to hear your advice at _that_ _table_', 'it certainly will not be taken.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
If _any_ part could tempt _you_ to act, I suppose it would be Anhalt, for he is a clergyman,
you know.
subQuotationList: ['If _any_ part could tempt _you_ to act, I suppose it would be Anhalt,', 'for he is a clergyman,\nyou know.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
_That_ circumstance would by no means tempt me, for I
should be sorry to make the character ridiculous by bad acting. It must
be very difficult to keep Anhalt from appearing a formal, solemn
lecturer; and the man who chuses the profession itself is, perhaps, one
of the last who would wish to represent it on the stage.
subQuotationList:
['_That_ circumstance would by no means tempt me,', 'for I
should be sorry to make the character ridiculous by bad acting. It must
be very difficult to keep Anhalt from appearing a formal, solemn
lecturer; and the man who chuses the profession itself is, perhaps, one
of the last who would wish to represent it on the stage.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Fanny, we want your
services.
subQuotationList: ['Fanny,', 'we want your\nservices.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Oh! we do not want to disturb you from your seat. We do not want your
_present_ services. We shall only want you in our play. You must be
Cottager's wife.
subQuotationList: ["Oh! we do not want to disturb you from your seat. We do not want your\n_present_ services. We shall only want you in our play. You must be\nCottager's wife."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Me! Indeed you must excuse me. I could not act anything if you were to
give me the world. No, indeed, I cannot act.
subQuotationList: ['Me!', 'Indeed you must excuse me. I could not act anything if you were to\ngive me the world. No, indeed, I cannot act.']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
Indeed, but you must, for we cannot excuse you. It need not frighten
you: it is a nothing of a part, a mere nothing, not above half a dozen
speeches altogether, and it will not much signify if nobody hears a
word you say; so you may be as creep-mouse as you like, but we must
have you to look at.
subQuotationList:
['Indeed, but you must, for we cannot excuse you. It need not frighten
you: it is a nothing of a part, a mere nothing, not above half a dozen
speeches altogether, and it will not much signify if nobody hears a
word you say; so you may be as creep-mouse as you like, but we must
have you to look at.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
If you are afraid of half a dozen speeches, what would you do with such a part as mine? I have forty-two to
learn.
subQuotationList: ['If you are afraid of half a dozen speeches,', 'what would you do with such a part as mine? I have forty-two to\nlearn.']
speaker: Mr. Rushworth
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText: It is not that I am afraid of learning by heart, but I really cannot act.
subQuotationList: ['It is not that I am afraid of learning by heart,', 'but I really cannot act.']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
Yes, yes, you can act well enough for _us_. Learn your part, and we
will teach you all the rest. You have only two scenes, and as I shall
be Cottager, I'll put you in and push you about, and you will do it
very well, I'll answer for it.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, yes, you can act well enough for _us_. Learn your part, and we
will teach you all the rest. You have only two scenes, and as I shall
be Cottager, I'll put you in and push you about, and you will do it
very well, I'll answer for it."]
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
No, indeed, Mr. Bertram, you must excuse me. You cannot have an idea.
It would be absolutely impossible for me. If I were to undertake it, I
should only disappoint you.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, Mr. Bertram, you must excuse me. You cannot have an idea.\nIt would be absolutely impossible for me. If I were to undertake it, I\nshould only disappoint you.']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
Phoo! Phoo! Do not be so shamefaced. You'll do it very well. Every
allowance will be made for you. We do not expect perfection. You must
get a brown gown, and a white apron, and a mob cap, and we must make
you a few wrinkles, and a little of the crowsfoot at the corner of your
eyes, and you will be a very proper, little old woman.
subQuotationList:

speaker: Tom Bertram

quoteText: You must excuse me, indeed you must excuse me,
subQuotationList: ['You must excuse me, indeed you must excuse me,']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Tom Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
What a piece of work here
is about nothing: I am quite ashamed of you, Fanny, to make such a
difficulty of obliging your cousins in a trifle of this sort   so kind as
they are to you! Take the part with a good grace, and let us hear no
more of the matter, I entreat.
subQuotationList:
['What a piece of work here
is about nothing: I am quite ashamed of you, Fanny, to make such a
difficulty of obliging your cousins in a trifle of this sort   so kind as
they are to you! Take the part with a good grace, and let us hear no
more of the matter, I entreat.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris
referringExpression: Mrs Norris completed the whole by thus addressing her in a whisper at once angry and audible
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris']]]

quoteText:
Do not urge her, madam, It is not fair to urge her in
this manner. You see she does not like to act. Let her chuse for
herself, as well as the rest of us. Her judgment may be quite as safely
trusted. Do not urge her any more.
subQuotationList:
['Do not urge her, madam,', 'It is not fair to urge her in
this manner. You see she does not like to act. Let her chuse for
herself, as well as the rest of us. Her judgment may be quite as safely
trusted. Do not urge her any more.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Mrs. Norris']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
I am not going to urge her, but I shall
think her a very obstinate, ungrateful girl, if she does not do what
her aunt and cousins wish her   very ungrateful, indeed, considering who
and what she is.
subQuotationList:
['I am not going to urge her,', 'but I shall
think her a very obstinate, ungrateful girl, if she does not do what
her aunt and cousins wish her   very ungrateful, indeed, considering who
and what she is.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText: I do not like my situation: this _place_ is too hot for me,
subQuotationList: ['I do not like my situation: this _place_ is too hot for me,']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: Miss Crawford looking for a moment with astonished eyes at Mrs Norris and then at Fanny whose tears were beginning to shew themselves immediately said

quoteText:
Never mind, my dear Miss Price, this is a cross evening: everybody is
cross and teasing, but do not let us mind them
subQuotationList: ['Never mind, my dear Miss Price, this is a cross evening: everybody is\ncross and teasing, but do not let us mind them']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: saying to her in a kind low whisper as she placed herself
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
But there will not be the smallest difficulty
in filling it, We have but to speak the word; we may pick
and chuse. I could name, at this moment, at least six young men within
six miles of us, who are wild to be admitted into our company, and
there are one or two that would not disgrace us: I should not be afraid
to trust either of the Olivers or Charles Maddox. Tom Oliver is a very
clever fellow, and Charles Maddox is as gentlemanlike a man as you will
see anywhere, so I will take my horse early to-morrow morning and ride
over to Stoke, and settle with one of them.
subQuotationList:
['But there will not be the smallest difficulty
in filling it,', 'We have but to speak the word; we may pick
and chuse. I could name, at this moment, at least six young men within
six miles of us, who are wild to be admitted into our company, and
there are one or two that would not disgrace us: I should not be afraid
to trust either of the Olivers or Charles Maddox. Tom Oliver is a very
clever fellow, and Charles Maddox is as gentlemanlike a man as you will
see anywhere, so I will take my horse early to-morrow morning and ride
over to Stoke, and settle with one of them.']
speaker: Tom Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram']]]

quoteText:
As
far as I am concerned, I can have no objection to anything that you all
think eligible. Have I ever seen either of the gentlemen? Yes, Mr.
Charles Maddox dined at my sister's one day, did not he, Henry? A
quiet-looking young man. I remember him. Let _him_ be applied to, if
you please, for it will be less unpleasant to me than to have a perfect
stranger.
subQuotationList:
["As
far as I am concerned, I can have no objection to anything that you all
think eligible. Have I ever seen either of the gentlemen? Yes, Mr.
Charles Maddox dined at my sister's one day, did not he, Henry? A
quiet-looking young man. I remember him. Let _him_ be applied to, if
you please, for it will be less unpleasant to me than to have a perfect
stranger."]
speaker: Mary Crawford
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
the Mansfield theatricals
would enliven the whole neighbourhood exceedingly,
subQuotationList: ['the Mansfield theatricals\nwould enliven the whole neighbourhood exceedingly,']
speaker: Julia Bertram
addressees: ['Lady Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mr. Yates', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Maria Bertram', 'Edmund']
referringExpression: Julia who had scarcely opened her lips before observed

quoteText:
I am not very sanguine as to our play, and I can tell Mr.
Maddox that I shall shorten some of _his_ speeches, and a great many of
_my_ _own_, before we rehearse together. It will be very disagreeable,
and by no means what I expected.
subQuotationList:
['I am not very sanguine as to our play,', 'and I can tell Mr.
Maddox that I shall shorten some of _his_ speeches, and a great many of
_my_ _own_, before we rehearse together. It will be very disagreeable,
and by no means what I expected.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: said Miss Crawford in an undervoice to Fanny

quoteText: Come in
subQuotationList: ['Come in']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: Can I speak with you, Fanny, for a few minutes?
subQuotationList: ['Can I speak with you, Fanny, for a few minutes?']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: Yes, certainly.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, certainly.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: I want to consult. I want your opinion.
subQuotationList: ['I want to consult. I want your opinion.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: My opinion!
subQuotationList: ['My opinion!']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Yes, your advice and opinion. I do not know what to do. This acting
scheme gets worse and worse, you see. They have chosen almost as bad a
play as they could, and now, to complete the business, are going to ask
the help of a young man very slightly known to any of us. This is the
end of all the privacy and propriety which was talked about at first. I
know no harm of Charles Maddox; but the excessive intimacy which must
spring from his being admitted among us in this manner is highly
objectionable, the _more_ than intimacy   the familiarity. I cannot think
of it with any patience; and it does appear to me an evil of such
magnitude as must, _if_ _possible_, be prevented. Do not you see it in
the same light?
subQuotationList:
['Yes, your advice and opinion. I do not know what to do. This acting
scheme gets worse and worse, you see. They have chosen almost as bad a
play as they could, and now, to complete the business, are going to ask
the help of a young man very slightly known to any of us. This is the
end of all the privacy and propriety which was talked about at first. I
know no harm of Charles Maddox; but the excessive intimacy which must
spring from his being admitted among us in this manner is highly
objectionable, the _more_ than intimacy   the familiarity. I cannot think
of it with any patience; and it does appear to me an evil of such
magnitude as must, _if_ _possible_, be prevented. Do not you see it in
the same light?']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText: Yes; but what can be done? Your brother is so determined.
subQuotationList: ['Yes; but what can be done? Your brother is so determined.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
There is but _one_ thing to be done, Fanny. I must take Anhalt myself.
I am well aware that nothing else will quiet Tom.
subQuotationList: ['There is but _one_ thing to be done, Fanny. I must take Anhalt myself.\nI am well aware that nothing else will quiet Tom.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
It is not at all what I like, No man can like being
driven into the _appearance_ of such inconsistency. After being known
to oppose the scheme from the beginning, there is absurdity in the face
of my joining them _now_, when they are exceeding their first plan in
every respect; but I can think of no other alternative. Can you,
Fanny?
subQuotationList:
['It is not at all what I like,', 'No man can like being
driven into the _appearance_ of such inconsistency. After being known
to oppose the scheme from the beginning, there is absurdity in the face
of my joining them _now_, when they are exceeding their first plan in
every respect; but I can think of no other alternative. Can you,
Fanny?']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Henry Crawford', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText: No, not immediately, but
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'not immediately, but']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
But what? I see your judgment is not with me. Think it a little over.
Perhaps you are not so much aware as I am of the mischief that _may_,
of the unpleasantness that _must_ arise from a young man's being
received in this manner: domesticated among us; authorised to come at
all hours, and placed suddenly on a footing which must do away all
restraints. To think only of the licence which every rehearsal must
tend to create. It is all very bad! Put yourself in Miss Crawford's
place, Fanny. Consider what it would be to act Amelia with a stranger.
She has a right to be felt for, because she evidently feels for
herself. I heard enough of what she said to you last night to
understand her unwillingness to be acting with a stranger; and as she
probably engaged in the part with different expectations   perhaps
without considering the subject enough to know what was likely to be   it
would be ungenerous, it would be really wrong to expose her to it. Her
feelings ought to be respected. Does it not strike you so, Fanny? You
hesitate.
subQuotationList:
["But what? I see your judgment is not with me. Think it a little over.
Perhaps you are not so much aware as I am of the mischief that _may_,
of the unpleasantness that _must_ arise from a young man's being
received in this manner: domesticated among us; authorised to come at
all hours, and placed suddenly on a footing which must do away all
restraints. To think only of the licence which every rehearsal must
tend to create. It is all very bad! Put yourself in Miss Crawford's
place, Fanny. Consider what it would be to act Amelia with a stranger.
She has a right to be felt for, because she evidently feels for
herself. I heard enough of what she said to you last night to
understand her unwillingness to be acting with a stranger; and as she
probably engaged in the part with different expectations   perhaps
without considering the subject enough to know what was likely to be   it
would be ungenerous, it would be really wrong to expose her to it. Her
feelings ought to be respected. Does it not strike you so, Fanny? You
hesitate."]
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
I am sorry for Miss Crawford; but I am more sorry to see you drawn in
to do what you had resolved against, and what you are known to think
will be disagreeable to my uncle. It will be such a triumph to the
others!
subQuotationList:
['I am sorry for Miss Crawford; but I am more sorry to see you drawn in
to do what you had resolved against, and what you are known to think
will be disagreeable to my uncle. It will be such a triumph to the
others!']
speaker: Fanny Price
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Crawford'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Mr. Rushworth', 'Mr. Yates', 'Mary Crawford', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Tom Bertram']]]

quoteText:
They will not have much cause of triumph when they see how infamously
I act. But, however, triumph there certainly will be, and I must brave
it. But if I can be the means of restraining the publicity of the
business, of limiting the exhibition, of concentrating our folly, I
shall be well repaid. As I am now, I have no influence, I can do
nothing: I have offended them, and they will not hear me; but when I
have put them in good-humour by this concession, I am not without hopes
of persuading them to confine the representation within a much smaller
circle than they are now in the high road for. This will be a material
gain. My object is to confine it to Mrs. Rushworth and the Grants. Will
not this be worth gaining?
subQuotationList:
['They will not have much cause of triumph when they see how infamously
I act. But, however, triumph there certainly will be, and I must brave

speaker: Edmund
