quite determine what. I had two or three ideas."]
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
And I have two or three ideas also, and one of them is,
that very little of your plan for Thornton Lacey will ever be put in
practice. I must be satisfied with rather less ornament and beauty. I
think the house and premises may be made comfortable, and given the air
of a gentleman's residence, without any very heavy expense, and that
must suffice me; and, I hope, may suffice all who care about me.
subQuotationList:
['And I have two or three ideas also,', "and one of them is,
that very little of your plan for Thornton Lacey will ever be put in
practice. I must be satisfied with rather less ornament and beauty. I
think the house and premises may be made comfortable, and given the air
of a gentleman's residence, without any very heavy expense, and that
must suffice me; and, I hope, may suffice all who care about me."]
speaker: Edmund
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
There, I will
stake my last like a woman of spirit. No cold prudence for me. I am not
born to sit still and do nothing. If I lose the game, it shall not be
from not striving for it.
subQuotationList:
['There, I will
stake my last like a woman of spirit. No cold prudence for me. I am not
born to sit still and do nothing. If I lose the game, it shall not be
from not striving for it.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']
referringExpression: Miss Crawford a little suspicious and resentful of a certain tone of voice and a certain halflook attending the last expression of his hope made a hasty finish of her dealings with William Price and securing his knave at an exorbitant rate exclaimed

quoteText:
My plan may not be the best possible: I had not many minutes to form
it in; but you must do a good deal. The place deserves it, and you will
find yourself not satisfied with much less than it is capable of.
(Excuse me, your ladyship must not see your cards. There, let them lie
just before you.) The place deserves it, Bertram. You talk of giving it
the air of a gentleman's residence. _That_ will be done by the removal
of the farmyard; for, independent of that terrible nuisance, I never
saw a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air of a
gentleman's residence, so much the look of a something above a mere
parsonage-house   above the expenditure of a few hundreds a year. It is
not a scrambling collection of low single rooms, with as many roofs as
windows; it is not cramped into the vulgar compactness of a square
farmhouse: it is a solid, roomy, mansion-like looking house, such as
one might suppose a respectable old country family had lived in from
generation to generation, through two centuries at least, and were now
spending from two to three thousand a year in.
subQuotationList:
["My plan may not be the best possible: I had not many minutes to form
it in; but you must do a good deal. The place deserves it, and you will
find yourself not satisfied with much less than it is capable of.

just before you.) The place deserves it, Bertram. You talk of giving it
the air of a gentleman's residence. _That_ will be done by the removal
of the farmyard; for, independent of that terrible nuisance, I never
saw a house of the kind which had in itself so much the air of a

speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
Have you ever seen the place? The air of a gentleman's residence,
therefore, you cannot but give it, if you do anything. But it is
capable of much more. (Let me see, Mary; Lady Bertram bids a dozen for
that queen; no, no, a dozen is more than it is worth. Lady Bertram does
not bid a dozen. She will have nothing to say to it. Go on, go on.) By
some such improvements as I have suggested (I do not really require you
to proceed upon my plan, though, by the bye, I doubt anybody's striking
out a better) you may give it a higher character. You may raise it into
a _place_. From being the mere gentleman's residence, it becomes, by
judicious improvement, the residence of a man of education, taste,
modern manners, good connexions. All this may be stamped on it; and
that house receive such an air as to make its owner be set down as the
great landholder of the parish by every creature travelling the road;
especially as there is no real squire's house to dispute the point   a
circumstance, between ourselves, to enhance the value of such a
situation in point of privilege and independence beyond all
calculation. _You_ think with me, I hope
subQuotationList:
['Have you ever seen the place?', "The air of a gentleman's residence,
therefore, you cannot but give it, if you do anything. But it is
capable of much more. (Let me see, Mary; Lady Bertram bids a dozen for

a _place_. From being the mere gentleman's residence, it becomes, by

circumstance, between ourselves, to enhance the value of such a
situation in point of privilege and independence beyond all
calculation. _You_ think with me, I hope"]
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
No, no, you must not part with the queen. You have bought her too
dearly, and your brother does not offer half her value. No, no, sir,
hands off, hands off. Your sister does not part with the queen. She is
quite determined. The game will be yours, it
will certainly be yours.
subQuotationList:
['No, no, you must not part with the queen. You have bought her too
dearly, and your brother does not offer half her value. No, no, sir,
hands off, hands off. Your sister does not part with the queen. She is
quite determined. The game will be yours,', 'it
will certainly be yours.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText: And Fanny had much rather it were William's, Poor Fanny! not allowed to cheat herself as she wishes!
subQuotationList: ["And Fanny had much rather it were William's,", 'Poor Fanny! not allowed to cheat herself as she wishes!']
speaker: Edmund
addressees: ['Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
Mr. Bertram, you know
Henry to be such a capital improver, that you cannot possibly engage in
anything of the sort at Thornton Lacey without accepting his help. Only
think how useful he was at Sotherton! Only think what grand things were
produced there by our all going with him one hot day in August to drive
about the grounds, and see his genius take fire. There we went, and
there we came home again; and what was done there is not to be told!
subQuotationList:
['Mr. Bertram,', 'you know
Henry to be such a capital improver, that you cannot possibly engage in
anything of the sort at Thornton Lacey without accepting his help. Only
think how useful he was at Sotherton! Only think what grand things were
produced there by our all going with him one hot day in August to drive
about the grounds, and see his genius take fire. There we went, and
there we came home again; and what was done there is not to be told!']
speaker: Mary Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edmund']], [['Edmund'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Edmund'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mr. Rushworth', 'Edmund', 'Julia Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText:
I cannot say there was much done at
Sotherton; but it was a hot day, and we were all walking after each
other, and bewildered.
subQuotationList: ['I cannot say there was much done at\nSotherton; but it was a hot day, and we were all walking after each\nother, and bewildered.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']
referringExpression: he shook his head at his sister and laughingly replied

quoteText:
I should be sorry to
have my powers of _planning_ judged of by the day at Sotherton. I see
things very differently now. Do not think of me as I appeared then.
subQuotationList: ['I should be sorry to\nhave my powers of _planning_ judged of by the day at Sotherton. I see\nthings very differently now. Do not think of me as I appeared then.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
referringExpression: he added in a low voice directed solely at Fanny

quoteText:
Sotherton! Yes, that is a place,
indeed, and we had a charming day there. William, you are quite out of
luck; but the next time you come, I hope dear Mr. and Mrs. Rushworth
will be at home, and I am sure I can answer for your being kindly
received by both. Your cousins are not of a sort to forget their
relations, and Mr. Rushworth is a most amiable man. They are at
Brighton now, you know; in one of the best houses there, as Mr.
Rushworth's fine fortune gives them a right to be. I do not exactly
know the distance, but when you get back to Portsmouth, if it is not
very far off, you ought to go over and pay your respects to them; and I
could send a little parcel by you that I want to get conveyed to your
cousins.
subQuotationList:
["Sotherton! Yes, that is a place,
indeed, and we had a charming day there. William, you are quite out of
luck; but the next time you come, I hope dear Mr. and Mrs. Rushworth

speaker: Mrs. Norris
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Sir Thomas']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Maria Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth'], ['William Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth'], ['William Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Mr. Rushworth'], ['William Price']]]

subQuotationList: ['I should be very happy, aunt; but Brighton is almost by Beachey Head;\nand if I could get so far, I could not expect to be welcome in such a\nsmart place as that   poor scrubby midshipman as I am.']
speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
I do not advise your going to Brighton, William, as I trust you may
soon have more convenient opportunities of meeting; but my daughters
would be happy to see their cousins anywhere; and you will find Mr.
Rushworth most sincerely disposed to regard all the connexions of our
family as his own.
subQuotationList:
['I do not advise your going to Brighton, William, as I trust you may
soon have more convenient opportunities of meeting; but my daughters
would be happy to see their cousins anywhere; and you will find Mr.
Rushworth most sincerely disposed to regard all the connexions of our
family as his own.']
speaker: Sir Thomas
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['William Price', 'Fanny Price'], ['William Price'], ['Mr. Rushworth'], ['Edmund', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Lady Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['Mr. Rushworth']]]

quoteText:
I would rather find him private secretary to the First Lord than
anything else,
subQuotationList: ['I would rather find him private secretary to the First Lord than\nanything else,']
speaker: William Price

quoteText:
I want to be your neighbour, Sir Thomas, as you have, perhaps, heard
me telling Miss Price. May I hope for your acquiescence, and for your
not influencing your son against such a tenant?
subQuotationList: ['I want to be your neighbour, Sir Thomas, as you have, perhaps, heard\nme telling Miss Price. May I hope for your acquiescence, and for your\nnot influencing your son against such a tenant?']
speaker: Henry Crawford
referringExpression: Henry Crawford addressed himself on the same subject to Sir Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText:
It is the only way, sir, in
which I could _not_ wish you established as a permanent neighbour; but
I hope, and believe, that Edmund will occupy his own house at Thornton
Lacey. Edmund, am I saying too much?
subQuotationList:
['It is the only way, sir, in
which I could _not_ wish you established as a permanent neighbour; but
I hope, and believe, that Edmund will occupy his own house at Thornton
Lacey. Edmund, am I saying too much?']
speaker: Sir Thomas

quoteText:
Certainly, sir, I have no idea but of residence. But, Crawford, though
I refuse you as a tenant, come to me as a friend. Consider the house as
half your own every winter, and we will add to the stables on your own
improved plan, and with all the improvements of your improved plan that
may occur to you this spring.
subQuotationList:
['Certainly, sir, I have no idea but of residence. But, Crawford, though
I refuse you as a tenant, come to me as a friend. Consider the house as
half your own every winter, and we will add to the stables on your own
improved plan, and with all the improvements of your improved plan that
may occur to you this spring.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Edmund'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
We shall be the losers, His going, though only
eight miles, will be an unwelcome contraction of our family circle; but
I should have been deeply mortified if any son of mine could reconcile
himself to doing less. It is perfectly natural that you should not have
thought much on the subject, Mr. Crawford. But a parish has wants and
claims which can be known only by a clergyman constantly resident, and
which no proxy can be capable of satisfying to the same extent. Edmund
might, in the common phrase, do the duty of Thornton, that is, he might
read prayers and preach, without giving up Mansfield Park: he might
ride over every Sunday, to a house nominally inhabited, and go through
divine service; he might be the clergyman of Thornton Lacey every
seventh day, for three or four hours, if that would content him. But it
will not. He knows that human nature needs more lessons than a weekly
sermon can convey; and that if he does not live among his parishioners,
and prove himself, by constant attention, their well-wisher and friend,
he does very little either for their good or his own.
subQuotationList:
['We shall be the losers,', 'His going, though only
eight miles, will be an unwelcome contraction of our family circle; but
I should have been deeply mortified if any son of mine could reconcile
himself to doing less. It is perfectly natural that you should not have

and prove himself, by constant attention, their well-wisher and friend,
he does very little either for their good or his own.']
speaker: Sir Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Maria Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Tom Bertram', 'Lady Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Sir Thomas']], [['Edmund'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Tom Bertram'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Tom Bertram', 'Edmund'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText:
I repeat again, that Thornton Lacey is the only
house in the neighbourhood in which I should _not_ be happy to wait on
Mr. Crawford as occupier.
subQuotationList: ['I repeat again,', 'that Thornton Lacey is the only\nhouse in the neighbourhood in which I should _not_ be happy to wait on\nMr. Crawford as occupier.']
speaker: Sir Thomas

quoteText:
Sir Thomas, undoubtedly understands the duty of a
parish priest. We must hope his son may prove that _he_ knows it too.
subQuotationList: ['Sir Thomas,', 'undoubtedly understands the duty of a\nparish priest. We must hope his son may prove that _he_ knows it too.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas']], [['Edmund', 'Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas', 'Fanny Price', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Dr. Grant', 'Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'William Price'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText:
This is the assembly night, If I were at Portsmouth I
should be at it, perhaps.
subQuotationList: ['This is the assembly night,', 'If I were at Portsmouth I\nshould be at it, perhaps.']
speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText: But you do not wish yourself at Portsmouth, William?
subQuotationList: ['But you do not wish yourself at Portsmouth, William?']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
No, Fanny, that I do not. I shall have enough of Portsmouth and of
dancing too, when I cannot have you. And I do not know that there would
be any good in going to the assembly, for I might not get a partner.
The Portsmouth girls turn up their noses at anybody who has not a
commission. One might as well be nothing as a midshipman. One _is_
nothing, indeed. You remember the Gregorys; they are grown up amazing
fine girls, but they will hardly speak to _me_, because Lucy is courted
by a lieutenant.
subQuotationList:
['No, Fanny, that I do not. I shall have enough of Portsmouth and of
dancing too, when I cannot have you. And I do not know that there would
be any good in going to the assembly, for I might not get a partner.
The Portsmouth girls turn up their noses at anybody who has not a
commission. One might as well be nothing as a midshipman. One _is_
nothing, indeed. You remember the Gregorys; they are grown up amazing
fine girls, but they will hardly speak to _me_, because Lucy is courted
by a lieutenant.']
speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
Oh! shame, shame! But never mind it, William It is not worth minding. It is no
reflection on _you_; it is no more than what the greatest admirals have
all experienced, more or less, in their time. You must think of that,
you must try to make up your mind to it as one of the hardships which
fall to every sailor's share, like bad weather and hard living, only
with this advantage, that there will be an end to it, that there will
come a time when you will have nothing of that sort to endure. When you
are a lieutenant! only think, William, when you are a lieutenant, how
little you will care for any nonsense of this kind.
subQuotationList:
['Oh! shame, shame! But never mind it, William', "It is not worth minding. It is no
reflection on _you_; it is no more than what the greatest admirals have
all experienced, more or less, in their time. You must think of that,
you must try to make up your mind to it as one of the hardships which
fall to every sailor's share, like bad weather and hard living, only
with this advantage, that there will be an end to it, that there will
come a time when you will have nothing of that sort to endure. When you
are a lieutenant! only think, William, when you are a lieutenant, how
little you will care for any nonsense of this kind."]
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Price']], [['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price']]]

quoteText:
I begin to think I shall never be a lieutenant, Fanny. Everybody gets
made but me.
subQuotationList: ['I begin to think I shall never be a lieutenant, Fanny. Everybody gets\nmade but me.']
speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']

quoteText:
Oh! my dear William, do not talk so; do not be so desponding. My uncle
says nothing, but I am sure he will do everything in his power to get
you made. He knows, as well as you do, of what consequence it is.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! my dear William, do not talk so; do not be so desponding. My uncle\nsays nothing, but I am sure he will do everything in his power to get\nyou made. He knows, as well as you do, of what consequence it is.']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['William Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['William Price']]]

quoteText: Are you fond of dancing, Fanny?
subQuotationList: ['Are you fond of dancing, Fanny?']
speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText: Yes, very; only I am soon tired.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, very; only I am soon tired.']
speaker: Fanny Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
I should like to go to a ball with you and see you dance. Have you
never any balls at Northampton? I should like to see you dance, and I'd
dance with you if you _would_, for nobody would know who I was here,
and I should like to be your partner once more. We used to jump about
together many a time, did not we? when the hand-organ was in the
street? I am a pretty good dancer in my way, but I dare say you are a
better.
subQuotationList:
["I should like to go to a ball with you and see you dance. Have you
never any balls at Northampton? I should like to see you dance, and I'd

together many a time, did not we? when the hand-organ was in the

speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['William Price', 'Fanny Price'], ['William Price', 'Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Is not
Fanny a very good dancer, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Is not\nFanny a very good dancer, sir?']
speaker: William Price
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
I am sorry to say that I am unable to
answer your question. I have never seen Fanny dance since she was a
little girl; but I trust we shall both think she acquits herself like a
gentlewoman when we do see her, which, perhaps, we may have an
opportunity of doing ere long.
subQuotationList:
['I am sorry to say that I am unable to
answer your question. I have never seen Fanny dance since she was a
little girl; but I trust we shall both think she acquits herself like a
gentlewoman when we do see her, which, perhaps, we may have an
opportunity of doing ere long.']
speaker: Sir Thomas
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
I have had the pleasure of seeing your sister dance, Mr. Price, and will engage to answer every
inquiry which you can make on the subject, to your entire satisfaction.
But I believe it must be at some
other time. There is _one_ person in company who does not like to have
Miss Price spoken of.
subQuotationList:
['I have had the pleasure of seeing your sister dance, Mr. Price,', 'and will engage to answer every
inquiry which you can make on the subject, to your entire satisfaction.
But I believe', 'it must be at some
other time. There is _one_ person in company who does not like to have
Miss Price spoken of.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
addressees: ['Edmund', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']

quoteText:
Come, Fanny, Fanny, what are you about? We are going. Do not you see
your aunt is going? Quick, quick! I cannot bear to keep good old Wilcox
waiting. You should always remember the coachman and horses. My dear
Sir Thomas, we have settled it that the carriage should come back for
you, and Edmund and William.
subQuotationList:
['Come, Fanny, Fanny, what are you about? We are going. Do not you see
your aunt is going? Quick, quick! I cannot bear to keep good old Wilcox
waiting. You should always remember the coachman and horses. My dear
Sir Thomas, we have settled it that the carriage should come back for
you, and Edmund and William.']
speaker: Mrs. Norris
addressees: ['Edmund', 'Henry Crawford', 'William Price', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mary Crawford', 'Dr. Grant', 'Mrs. Grant', 'Sir Thomas']
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Mrs. Norris'], ['Edmund'], ['William Price']]]

quoteText:
I do not like, William, that you should
leave Northamptonshire without this indulgence. It would give me
pleasure to see you both dance. You spoke of the balls at Northampton.
Your cousins have occasionally attended them; but they would not
altogether suit us now. The fatigue would be too much for your aunt. I
believe we must not think of a Northampton ball. A dance at home would
be more eligible; and if
subQuotationList:

speaker: Sir Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['William Price'], ['Fanny Price', 'William Price'], ['Fanny Price', 'William Price'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
Ah, my dear Sir Thomas! I knew what was
coming. I knew what you were going to say. If dear Julia were at home,
or dearest Mrs. Rushworth at Sotherton, to afford a reason, an occasion
for such a thing, you would be tempted to give the young people a dance
at Mansfield. I know you would. If _they_ were at home to grace the
ball, a ball you would have this very Christmas. Thank your uncle,
William, thank your uncle!
subQuotationList:
['Ah, my dear Sir Thomas!', 'I knew what was
coming. I knew what you were going to say. If dear Julia were at home,
or dearest Mrs. Rushworth at Sotherton, to afford a reason, an occasion

at Mansfield. I know you would. If _they_ were at home to grace the
ball, a ball you would have this very Christmas. Thank your uncle,

speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionTextsList: [['my dear Sir Thomas'], ['you', 'dear Julia', 'you', 'the young people', 'you', 'they', 'you', 'your uncle', 'William', 'your uncle']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas']], [['Sir Thomas'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'William Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Julia Bertram'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['William Price'], ['Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
My daughters, have their
pleasures at Brighton, and I hope are very happy; but the dance which I
think of giving at Mansfield will be for their cousins. Could we be all
assembled, our satisfaction would undoubtedly be more complete, but the
absence of some is not to debar the others of amusement.
subQuotationList:
['My daughters,', 'have their

speaker: Sir Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram']], [['Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram'], ['William Price', 'Fanny Price'], ['Edmund', 'Maria Bertram', 'Fanny Price', 'Tom Bertram', 'Lady Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Lady Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris', 'Tom Bertram', 'Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText: But what shall you have by way of necklace? Shall not you wear your brother's cross?
subQuotationList: ['But what shall you have by way of necklace?', "Shall not you wear your brother's cross?"]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
You see what a collection I have, more by half than I ever
use or think of. I do not offer them as new. I offer nothing but an old
necklace. You must forgive the liberty, and oblige me.
subQuotationList: ['You see what a collection I have,', 'more by half than I ever\nuse or think of. I do not offer them as new. I offer nothing but an old\nnecklace. You must forgive the liberty, and oblige me.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
When I wear this necklace I
shall always think of you, and feel how very kind you
were.
subQuotationList: ['When I wear this necklace I\nshall always think of you,', 'and feel how very kind you\nwere.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
You must think of somebody else too, when you wear that necklace, You must think of Henry, for it was his choice
in the first place. He gave it to me, and with the necklace I make over
to you all the duty of remembering the original giver. It is to be a
family remembrancer. The sister is not to be in your mind without
bringing the brother too.
subQuotationList:
['You must think of somebody else too, when you wear that necklace,', 'You must think of Henry, for it was his choice
in the first place. He gave it to me, and with the necklace I make over
to you all the duty of remembering the original giver. It is to be a
family remembrancer. The sister is not to be in your mind without
bringing the brother too.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
My dear child, what are
you afraid of? Do you think Henry will claim the necklace as mine, and
fancy you did not come honestly by it? or are you imagining he would be
too much flattered by seeing round your lovely throat an ornament which
his money purchased three years ago, before he knew there was such a
throat in the world? or perhaps you suspect a
confederacy between us, and that what I am now doing is with his
knowledge and at his desire?
subQuotationList:
['My dear child,', 'what are
you afraid of? Do you think Henry will claim the necklace as mine, and
fancy you did not come honestly by it? or are you imagining he would be
too much flattered by seeing round your lovely throat an ornament which
his money purchased three years ago, before he knew there was such a
throat in the world? or perhaps', 'you suspect a
confederacy between us, and that what I am now doing is with his
knowledge and at his desire?']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
Well, then, to convince me that you suspect no trick, and are as
unsuspicious of compliment as I have always found you, take the
necklace and say no more about it. Its being a gift of my brother's
need not make the smallest difference in your accepting it, as I assure
you it makes none in my willingness to part with it. He is always
giving me something or other. I have such innumerable presents from him
that it is quite impossible for me to value or for him to remember
half. And as for this necklace, I do not suppose I have worn it six
times: it is very pretty, but I never think of it; and though you would
be most heartily welcome to any other in my trinket-box, you have
happened to fix on the very one which, if I have a choice, I would
rather part with and see in your possession than any other. Say no more
against it, I entreat you. Such a trifle is not worth half so many
words.
subQuotationList:
['Well, then,', "to convince me that you suspect no trick, and are as
unsuspicious of compliment as I have always found you, take the
necklace and say no more about it. Its being a gift of my brother's
need not make the smallest difference in your accepting it, as I assure
you it makes none in my willingness to part with it. He is always
giving me something or other. I have such innumerable presents from him
that it is quite impossible for me to value or for him to remember
half. And as for this necklace, I do not suppose I have worn it six
times: it is very pretty, but I never think of it; and though you would
be most heartily welcome to any other in my trinket-box, you have
happened to fix on the very one which, if I have a choice, I would
rather part with and see in your possession than any other. Say no more
against it, I entreat you. Such a trifle is not worth half so many
words."]
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Fanny, I beg your pardon for being here. I
came to look for you, and after waiting a little while in hope of your
coming in, was making use of your inkstand to explain my errand. You
will find the beginning of a note to yourself; but I can now speak my
business, which is merely to beg your acceptance of this little
trifle   a chain for William's cross. You ought to have had it a week
ago, but there has been a delay from my brother's not being in town by
several days so soon as I expected; and I have only just now received
it at Northampton. I hope you will like the chain itself, Fanny. I
endeavoured to consult the simplicity of your taste; but, at any rate,
I know you will be kind to my intentions, and consider it, as it really
is, a token of the love of one of your oldest friends.
subQuotationList:
['Fanny,', "I beg your pardon for being here. I
came to look for you, and after waiting a little while in hope of your
coming in, was making use of your inkstand to explain my errand. You

business, which is merely to beg your acceptance of this little
trifle   a chain for William's cross. You ought to have had it a week
ago, but there has been a delay from my brother's not being in town by
several days so soon as I expected; and I have only just now received
it at Northampton. I hope you will like the chain itself, Fanny. I
endeavoured to consult the simplicity of your taste; but, at any rate,
I know you will be kind to my intentions, and consider it, as it really
is, a token of the love of one of your oldest friends."]
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['William Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Tom Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Oh! cousin, stop
a moment, pray stop!
subQuotationList: ['Oh! cousin, stop\na moment, pray stop!']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
I cannot attempt to thank you, thanks are out of the question. I feel much more than I can
possibly express. Your goodness in thinking of me in such a way is
beyond
subQuotationList: ['I cannot attempt to thank you,', 'thanks are out of the question. I feel much more than I can\npossibly express. Your goodness in thinking of me in such a way is\nbeyond']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: If that is all you have to say, Fanny
subQuotationList: ['If that is all you have to say, Fanny']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: No, no, it is not. I want to consult you.
subQuotationList: ['No, no, it is not. I want to consult you.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Oh, this is beautiful indeed! This is the
very thing, precisely what I wished for! This is the only ornament I
have ever had a desire to possess. It will exactly suit my cross. They
must and shall be worn together. It comes, too, in such an acceptable
moment. Oh, cousin, you do not know how acceptable it is.
subQuotationList:
['Oh, this is beautiful indeed! This is the
very thing, precisely what I wished for! This is the only ornament I
have ever had a desire to possess. It will exactly suit my cross. They
must and shall be worn together. It comes, too, in such an acceptable
moment. Oh, cousin, you do not know how acceptable it is.']
speaker: Fanny Price
referringExpression: she could not help bursting forth

quoteText:
My dear Fanny, you feel these things a great deal too much. I am most
happy that you like the chain, and that it should be here in time for
to-morrow; but your thanks are far beyond the occasion. Believe me, I
have no pleasure in the world superior to that of contributing to
yours. No, I can safely say, I have no pleasure so complete, so
unalloyed. It is without a drawback.
subQuotationList:
['My dear Fanny, you feel these things a great deal too much. I am most
happy that you like the chain, and that it should be here in time for
to-morrow; but your thanks are far beyond the occasion. Believe me, I
have no pleasure in the world superior to that of contributing to
yours. No, I can safely say, I have no pleasure so complete, so
unalloyed. It is without a drawback.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: But what is it that you want to consult me about?
subQuotationList: ['But what is it that you want to consult me about?']
speaker: Edmund
referringExpression: Edmund after waiting a moment obliged her to bring down her mind from its heavenly flight by saying

quoteText:
Return the necklace! No, my dear Fanny, upon no account. It would be
mortifying her severely. There can hardly be a more unpleasant
sensation than the having anything returned on our hands which we have
given with a reasonable hope of its contributing to the comfort of a
friend. Why should she lose a pleasure which she has shewn herself so
deserving of?
subQuotationList:
['Return the necklace! No, my dear Fanny, upon no account. It would be
mortifying her severely. There can hardly be a more unpleasant
sensation than the having anything returned on our hands which we have
given with a reasonable hope of its contributing to the comfort of a
friend. Why should she lose a pleasure which she has shewn herself so
deserving of?']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText:
If it had been given to me in the first instance, I
should not have thought of returning it; but being her brother's
present, is not it fair to suppose that she would rather not part with
it, when it is not wanted?
subQuotationList:
['If it had been given to me in the first instance,', "I
should not have thought of returning it; but being her brother's
present, is not it fair to suppose that she would rather not part with
it, when it is not wanted?"]
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
She must not suppose it not wanted, not acceptable, at least: and its
having been originally her brother's gift makes no difference; for as
she was not prevented from offering, nor you from taking it on that
account, it ought not to prevent you from keeping it. No doubt it is
handsomer than mine, and fitter for a ballroom.
subQuotationList:
["She must not suppose it not wanted, not acceptable, at least: and its
having been originally her brother's gift makes no difference; for as
she was not prevented from offering, nor you from taking it on that
account, it ought not to prevent you from keeping it. No doubt it is
handsomer than mine, and fitter for a ballroom."]
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
No, it is not handsomer, not at all handsomer in its way, and, for my
purpose, not half so fit. The chain will agree with William's cross
beyond all comparison better than the necklace.
subQuotationList: ["No, it is not handsomer, not at all handsomer in its way, and, for my\npurpose, not half so fit. The chain will agree with William's cross\nbeyond all comparison better than the necklace."]
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
For one night, Fanny, for only one night, if it _be_ a sacrifice; I am
sure you will, upon consideration, make that sacrifice rather than give
pain to one who has been so studious of your comfort. Miss Crawford's
attentions to you have been   not more than you were justly entitled to   I
am the last person to think that _could_ _be_, but they have been
invariable; and to be returning them with what must have something the
_air_ of ingratitude, though I know it could never have the _meaning_,
is not in your nature, I am sure. Wear the necklace, as you are engaged
to do, to-morrow evening, and let the chain, which was not ordered with
any reference to the ball, be kept for commoner occasions. This is my
advice. I would not have the shadow of a coolness between the two whose
intimacy I have been observing with the greatest pleasure, and in whose
characters there is so much general resemblance in true generosity and
natural delicacy as to make the few slight differences, resulting
principally from situation, no reasonable hindrance to a perfect
friendship. I would not have the shadow of a coolness arise, between the two dearest objects
I have on earth.
subQuotationList:
["For one night, Fanny, for only one night, if it _be_ a sacrifice; I am
sure you will, upon consideration, make that sacrifice rather than give
pain to one who has been so studious of your comfort. Miss Crawford's

am the last person to think that _could_ _be_, but they have been

characters there is so much general resemblance in true generosity and
natural delicacy as to make the few slight differences, resulting
principally from situation, no reasonable hindrance to a perfect
friendship. I would not have the shadow of a coolness arise,", 'between the two dearest objects
I have on earth.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionTextsList: [['Fanny', 'you', 'your', 'Miss Crawford', 'you', 'you', 'they', 'them', 'your', 'you'], ['the two dearest objects\nI have on earth']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford', 'Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price', 'Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText:
Suppose I were to find him there again
to-day!
subQuotationList: ['Suppose I were to find him there again\nto-day!']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: Fanny, You look tired and fagged, Fanny. You have been walking too far.
subQuotationList: ['Fanny,', 'You look tired and fagged, Fanny. You have been walking too far.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText: No, I have not been out at all.
subQuotationList: ['No, I have not been out at all.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Then you have had fatigues within doors, which are worse. You had
better have gone out.
subQuotationList: ['Then you have had fatigues within doors, which are worse. You had\nbetter have gone out.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I come from Dr. Grant's, You may guess my
errand there, Fanny.
subQuotationList: ["I come from Dr. Grant's,", 'You may guess my\nerrand there, Fanny.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
I
wished to engage Miss Crawford for the two first dances,
subQuotationList: ['I\nwished to engage Miss Crawford for the two first dances,']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Yes, she is engaged to me; but she says it is to be the last time that she ever will
dance with me. She is not serious. I think, I hope, I am sure she is
not serious; but I would rather not hear it. She never has danced with
a clergyman, she says, and she never _will_. For my own sake, I could
wish there had been no ball just at   I mean not this very week, this
very day; to-morrow I leave home.
subQuotationList:
['Yes,', 'she is engaged to me; but', 'she says it is to be the last time that she ever will
dance with me. She is not serious. I think, I hope, I am sure she is
not serious; but I would rather not hear it. She never has danced with
a clergyman, she says, and she never _will_. For my own sake, I could
wish there had been no ball just at   I mean not this very week, this
very day; to-morrow I leave home.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Mary Crawford']], [['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText:
I am very sorry that anything
has occurred to distress you. This ought to be a day of pleasure. My
uncle meant it so.
subQuotationList: ['I am very sorry that anything\nhas occurred to distress you. This ought to be a day of pleasure. My\nuncle meant it so.']
speaker: Fanny Price
referringExpression: Fanny struggled for speech and said

quoteText:
Oh yes, yes! and it will be a day of pleasure. It will all end right.
I am only vexed for a moment. In fact, it is not that I consider the
ball as ill-timed; what does it signify? But, Fanny,
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, yes! and it will be a day of pleasure. It will all end right.\nI am only vexed for a moment. In fact, it is not that I consider the\nball as ill-timed; what does it signify? But, Fanny,']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
you know what all
this means. You see how it is; and could tell me, perhaps better than I
could tell you, how and why I am vexed. Let me talk to you a little.
You are a kind, kind listener. I have been pained by her manner this
morning, and cannot get the better of it. I know her disposition to be
as sweet and faultless as your own, but the influence of her former
companions makes her seem   gives to her conversation, to her professed
opinions, sometimes a tinge of wrong. She does not _think_ evil, but
she speaks it, speaks it in playfulness; and though I know it to be
playfulness, it grieves me to the soul.
subQuotationList:
['you know what all
this means. You see how it is; and could tell me, perhaps better than I

You are a kind, kind listener. I have been pained by her manner this
morning, and cannot get the better of it. I know her disposition to be

speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford']]]

quoteText: The effect of education,
subQuotationList: ['The effect of education,']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Yes, that uncle and aunt! They have
injured the finest mind; for sometimes, Fanny, I own to you, it does
appear more than manner: it appears as if the mind itself was tainted.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that uncle and aunt! They have\ninjured the finest mind; for sometimes, Fanny, I own to you, it does\nappear more than manner: it appears as if the mind itself was tainted.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
If you only want me as a
listener, cousin, I will be as useful as I can; but I am not qualified
for an adviser. Do not ask advice of _me_. I am not competent.
subQuotationList: ['If you only want me as a\nlistener, cousin, I will be as useful as I can; but I am not qualified\nfor an adviser. Do not ask advice of _me_. I am not competent.']
speaker: Fanny Price
referringExpression: Fanny imagined this to be an appeal to her judgment and therefore after a moments consideration said

quoteText:
You are right, Fanny, to protest against such an office, but you need
not be afraid. It is a subject on which I should never ask advice; it
is the sort of subject on which it had better never be asked; and few,
I imagine, do ask it, but when they want to be influenced against their
conscience. I only want to talk to you.
subQuotationList:
['You are right, Fanny, to protest against such an office, but you need
not be afraid. It is a subject on which I should never ask advice; it
is the sort of subject on which it had better never be asked; and few,
I imagine, do ask it, but when they want to be influenced against their
conscience. I only want to talk to you.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
One thing more. Excuse the liberty; but take care _how_ you talk to
me. Do not tell me anything now, which hereafter you may be sorry for.
The time may come
subQuotationList: ['One thing more. Excuse the liberty; but take care _how_ you talk to\nme. Do not tell me anything now, which hereafter you may be sorry for.\nThe time may come']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Dearest Fanny! you are all
considerate thought! But it is unnecessary here. The time will never
come. No such time as you allude to will ever come. I begin to think it
most improbable: the chances grow less and less; and even if it should,
there will be nothing to be remembered by either you or me that we need
be afraid of, for I can never be ashamed of my own scruples; and if
they are removed, it must be by changes that will only raise her
character the more by the recollection of the faults she once had. You
are the only being upon earth to whom I should say what I have said;
but you have always known my opinion of her; you can bear me witness,
Fanny, that I have never been blinded. How many a time have we talked
over her little errors! You need not fear me; I have almost given up
every serious idea of her; but I must be a blockhead indeed, if,
whatever befell me, I could think of your kindness and sympathy without
the sincerest gratitude.
subQuotationList:
['Dearest Fanny!', 'you are all
considerate thought! But it is unnecessary here. The time will never
come. No such time as you allude to will ever come. I begin to think it

every serious idea of her; but I must be a blockhead indeed, if,
whatever befell me, I could think of your kindness and sympathy without
the sincerest gratitude.']
speaker: Edmund
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Edmund', 'Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Yes, cousin, I am convinced
that _you_ would be incapable of anything else, though perhaps some
might not. I cannot be afraid of hearing anything you wish to say. Do
not check yourself. Tell me whatever you like.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, cousin, I am convinced
that _you_ would be incapable of anything else, though perhaps some
might not. I cannot be afraid of hearing anything you wish to say. Do
not check yourself. Tell me whatever you like.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: Yes, she looks very well. I sent Chapman to her.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'she looks very well. I sent Chapman to her.']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
Look well! Oh, yes! she has good reason to look
well with all her advantages: brought up in this family as she has
been, with all the benefit of her cousins' manners before her. Only
think, my dear Sir Thomas, what extraordinary advantages you and I have
been the means of giving her. The very gown you have been taking notice
of is your own generous present to her when dear Mrs. Rushworth
married. What would she have been if we had not taken her by the hand?
subQuotationList:
['Look well! Oh, yes!', "she has good reason to look
well with all her advantages: brought up in this family as she has
been, with all the benefit of her cousins' manners before her. Only
think, my dear Sir Thomas, what extraordinary advantages you and I have
been the means of giving her. The very gown you have been taking notice
of is your own generous present to her when dear Mrs. Rushworth
married. What would she have been if we had not taken her by the hand?"]
speaker: Mrs. Norris
mentionTextsList: [[], ['she', 'her', 'this family', 'she', 'her cousins', 'her', 'my dear Sir Thomas', 'you', 'her', 'you', 'your', 'her', 'Mrs. Rushworth', 'she', 'we', 'her']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Edmund', 'Julia Bertram', 'Lady Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Sir Thomas', 'Tom Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Edmund', 'Maria Bertram', 'Julia Bertram', 'Tom Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Mrs. Norris'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
You must dance
with me, Fanny; you must keep two dances for me; any two that you like,
except the first.
subQuotationList: ['You must dance\nwith me, Fanny; you must keep two dances for me; any two that you like,\nexcept the first.']
speaker: Edmund
referringExpression: Edmund who was holding open the door said as she passed him

quoteText:
Did he? Did
Edmund? That was like himself. No other man would have thought of it. I
honour him beyond expression.
subQuotationList: ['Did he? Did\nEdmund? That was like himself. No other man would have thought of it. I\nhonour him beyond expression.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: It must be so, my dear,
subQuotationList: ['It must be so, my dear,']
speaker: Sir Thomas
referringExpression: Sir Thomas smiled tried to encourage her and then looked too serious and said

quoteText: Yes, she does look very well, Chapman helped her to dress. I sent Chapman to her.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, she does look very well,', 'Chapman helped her to dress. I sent Chapman to her.']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
Ah!
ma'am, how much we want dear Mrs. Rushworth and Julia to-night!
subQuotationList: ["Ah!\nma'am, how much we want dear Mrs. Rushworth and Julia to-night!"]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Perhaps _you_ can tell me why my brother goes to
town to-morrow? He says he has business there, but will not tell me
what. The first time he ever denied me his confidence! But this is what
we all come to. All are supplanted sooner or later. Now, I must apply
to you for information. Pray, what is Henry going for?
subQuotationList:
['Perhaps _you_ can tell me why my brother goes to
town to-morrow? He says he has business there, but will not tell me
what. The first time he ever denied me his confidence! But this is what
we all come to. All are supplanted sooner or later. Now, I must apply
to you for information. Pray, what is Henry going for?']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: She meant to be giving her little heart a happy flutter and filling her with sensations of delightful selfconsequence and misinterpreting Fannys blushes still thought she must be doing so when she went to her after the two first dances and said
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
Well, then, I must suppose it to be
purely for the pleasure of conveying your brother, and of talking of
you by the way.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then,', 'I must suppose it to be\npurely for the pleasure of conveying your brother, and of talking of\nyou by the way.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
I am worn out with civility, I have been talking incessantly all night, and with nothing to say.
But with _you_, Fanny, there may be peace. You will not want to be
talked to. Let us have the luxury of silence.
subQuotationList: ['I am worn out with civility,', 'I have been talking incessantly all night, and with nothing to say.\nBut with _you_, Fanny, there may be peace. You will not want to be\ntalked to. Let us have the luxury of silence.']
speaker: Edmund

quoteText:
Poor Fanny! how soon she is knocked
up! Why, the sport is but just begun. I hope we shall keep it up these
two hours. How can you be tired so soon?
subQuotationList: ['Poor Fanny!', 'how soon she is knocked\nup! Why, the sport is but just begun. I hope we shall keep it up these\ntwo hours. How can you be tired so soon?']
speaker: William Price
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price']], [['Fanny Price'], ['William Price', 'Sir Thomas', 'Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
So soon! my good friend, it is three o'clock, and your sister is not
used to these sort of hours.
subQuotationList: ['So soon! my good friend,', "it is three o'clock, and your sister is not\nused to these sort of hours."]
speaker: Sir Thomas

quoteText:
Well, then, Fanny, you shall not get up to-morrow before I go. Sleep
as long as you can, and never mind me.
subQuotationList: ['Well, then, Fanny, you shall not get up to-morrow before I go. Sleep\nas long as you can, and never mind me.']
speaker: William Price

quoteText: Oh! William.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! William.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: What! Did she think of being up before you set off?
subQuotationList: ['What! Did she think of being up before you set off?']
speaker: Sir Thomas

quoteText:
Oh! yes, sir, I must get up and breakfast with him. It will be the last
time, you know; the last morning.
subQuotationList: ['Oh! yes, sir,', 'I must get up and breakfast with him. It will be the last\ntime, you know; the last morning.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
You had better not. He is to have breakfasted and be gone by half-past
nine. Mr. Crawford, I think you call for him at half-past nine?
subQuotationList: ['You had better not. He is to have breakfasted and be gone by half-past\nnine. Mr. Crawford, I think you call for him at half-past nine?']
speaker: Sir Thomas

quoteText:
Yes, half-past nine, and I shall be punctual, for there will be no kind
sister to get up for _me_.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, half-past nine,', 'and I shall be punctual, for there will be no kind\nsister to get up for _me_.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
I shall have
only a desolate house to hurry from. Your brother will find my ideas of
time and his own very different to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['I shall have\nonly a desolate house to hurry from. Your brother will find my ideas of\ntime and his own very different to-morrow.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
referringExpression: in a lower tone to Fanny

quoteText:
I cannot think what is the matter
with me, I feel
quite stupid. It must be sitting up so late last night. Fanny, you must
do something to keep me awake. I cannot work. Fetch the cards; I feel
so very stupid.
subQuotationList:
['I cannot think what is the matter
with me,', 'I feel
quite stupid. It must be sitting up so late last night. Fanny, you must
do something to keep me awake. I cannot work. Fetch the cards; I feel
so very stupid.']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
And _that_ makes thirty-one; four in hand and eight in crib. You
are to deal, ma'am; shall I deal for you?
subQuotationList: ["And _that_ makes thirty-one; four in hand and eight in crib. You\nare to deal, ma'am; shall I deal for you?"]
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: We miss our two young men,
subQuotationList: ['We miss our two young men,']
speaker: Sir Thomas

quoteText:
And there is no reason to suppose, but that his visits to us may now be tolerably frequent. As to
Edmund, we must learn to do without him. This will be the last winter
of his belonging to us, as he has done.
subQuotationList: ['And there is no reason to suppose,', 'but that his visits to us may now be tolerably frequent. As to\nEdmund, we must learn to do without him. This will be the last winter\nof his belonging to us, as he has done.']
speaker: Sir Thomas
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Fanny Price', 'Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund']]]

quoteText:
Yes, but I wish he was not going away. They are
all going away, I think. I wish they would stay at home.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'but I wish he was not going away. They are\nall going away, I think. I wish they would stay at home.']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
Sir Thomas, I have been thinking   and I am very glad we took Fanny as
we did, for now the others are away we feel the good of it.
subQuotationList: ['Sir Thomas, I have been thinking   and I am very glad we took Fanny as\nwe did, for now the others are away we feel the good of it.']
speaker: Lady Bertram
referringExpression: Lady Bertram agreed to it all with a calm Yes and at the end of a quarter of an hours silent consideration spontaneously observed
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Edmund', 'Julia Bertram', 'Maria Bertram', 'Tom Bertram'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
Very true.
We shew Fanny what a good girl we think her by praising her to her
face, she is now a very valuable companion. If we have been kind to
_her_, she is now quite as necessary to _us_.
subQuotationList:
['Very true.
We shew Fanny what a good girl we think her by praising her to her
face, she is now a very valuable companion. If we have been kind to
_her_, she is now quite as necessary to _us_.']
speaker: Sir Thomas
referringExpression: Sir Thomas immediately improved this compliment by adding
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Lady Bertram', 'Sir Thomas']]]

quoteText:
Yes, and it is a comfort to think that
we shall always have _her_.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'and it is a comfort to think that\nwe shall always have _her_.']
speaker: Lady Bertram

quoteText:
She will never leave us, I hope, till invited to some other
home that may reasonably promise her greater happiness than she knows
here.
subQuotationList: ['She will never leave us, I hope, till invited to some other\nhome that may reasonably promise her greater happiness than she knows\nhere.']
speaker: Sir Thomas
referringExpression: Sir Thomas paused half smiled glanced at his niece and then gravely replied

quoteText:
And _that_ is not very likely to be, Sir Thomas. Who should invite
her? Maria might be very glad to see her at Sotherton now and then, but
she would not think of asking her to live there; and I am sure she is
better off here; and besides, I cannot do without her.
subQuotationList:
['And _that_ is not very likely to be, Sir Thomas. Who should invite
her? Maria might be very glad to see her at Sotherton now and then, but
she would not think of asking her to live there; and I am sure she is
better off here; and besides, I cannot do without her.']
speaker: Lady Bertram
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Maria Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
And
how do _you_ like your cousin Edmund's staying away so long? Being the
only young person at home, I consider _you_ as the greatest sufferer.
You must miss him. Does his staying longer surprise you?
subQuotationList:
["And
how do _you_ like your cousin Edmund's staying away so long? Being the
only young person at home, I consider _you_ as the greatest sufferer.
You must miss him. Does his staying longer surprise you?"]
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
I do not know, Yes; I had not particularly
expected it.
subQuotationList: ['I do not know,', 'Yes; I had not particularly\nexpected it.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Perhaps he will always stay longer than he talks of. It is the general
way all young men do.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps he will always stay longer than he talks of. It is the general\nway all young men do.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: He did not, the only time he went to see Mr. Owen before.
subQuotationList: ['He did not, the only time he went to see Mr. Owen before.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
He finds the house more agreeable _now_. He is a very   a very pleasing
young man himself, and I cannot help being rather concerned at not
seeing him again before I go to London, as will now undoubtedly be the
case. I am looking for Henry every day, and as soon as he comes there
will be nothing to detain me at Mansfield. I should like to have seen
him once more, I confess. But you must give my compliments to him. Yes;
I think it must be compliments. Is not there a something wanted, Miss
Price, in our language   a something between compliments and   and love   to
suit the sort of friendly acquaintance we have had together? So many
months' acquaintance! But compliments may be sufficient here. Was his
letter a long one? Does he give you much account of what he is doing?
Is it Christmas gaieties that he is staying for?
subQuotationList:
["He finds the house more agreeable _now_. He is a very   a very pleasing
young man himself, and I cannot help being rather concerned at not
seeing him again before I go to London, as will now undoubtedly be the
case. I am looking for Henry every day, and as soon as he comes there
will be nothing to detain me at Mansfield. I should like to have seen
him once more, I confess. But you must give my compliments to him. Yes;
I think it must be compliments. Is not there a something wanted, Miss
Price, in our language   a something between compliments and   and love   to
suit the sort of friendly acquaintance we have had together? So many
months' acquaintance! But compliments may be sufficient here. Was his
letter a long one? Does he give you much account of what he is doing?
Is it Christmas gaieties that he is staying for?"]
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford', 'Edmund'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
I only heard a part of the letter; it was to my uncle; but I believe
it was very short; indeed I am sure it was but a few lines. All that I
heard was that his friend had pressed him to stay longer, and that he
had agreed to do so. A _few_ days longer, or _some_ days longer; I am
not quite sure which.
subQuotationList:
['I only heard a part of the letter; it was to my uncle; but I believe
it was very short; indeed I am sure it was but a few lines. All that I
heard was that his friend had pressed him to stay longer, and that he
had agreed to do so. A _few_ days longer, or _some_ days longer; I am
not quite sure which.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Oh! if he wrote to his father; but I thought it might have been to
Lady Bertram or you. But if he wrote to his father, no wonder he was
concise. Who could write chat to Sir Thomas? If he had written to you,
there would have been more particulars. You would have heard of balls
and parties. He would have sent you a description of everything and
everybody. How many Miss Owens are there?
subQuotationList:
['Oh! if he wrote to his father; but I thought it might have been to
Lady Bertram or you. But if he wrote to his father, no wonder he was
concise. Who could write chat to Sir Thomas? If he had written to you,
there would have been more particulars. You would have heard of balls
and parties. He would have sent you a description of everything and
everybody. How many Miss Owens are there?']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady Bertram'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Sir Thomas'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText: Three grown up.
subQuotationList: ['Three grown up.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText: Are they musical?
subQuotationList: ['Are they musical?']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: I do not at all know. I never heard.
subQuotationList: ['I do not at all know. I never heard.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
That is the first question, you know, which every woman who plays herself is
sure to ask about another. But it is very foolish to ask questions
about any young ladies   about any three sisters just grown up; for one
knows, without being told, exactly what they are: all very accomplished
and pleasing, and one very pretty. There is a beauty in every family;
it is a regular thing. Two play on the pianoforte, and one on the harp;
and all sing, or would sing if they were taught, or sing all the better
for not being taught; or something like it.
subQuotationList:
['That is the first question, you know,', 'which every woman who plays herself is
sure to ask about another. But it is very foolish to ask questions
about any young ladies   about any three sisters just grown up; for one
knows, without being told, exactly what they are: all very accomplished
and pleasing, and one very pretty. There is a beauty in every family;
it is a regular thing. Two play on the pianoforte, and one on the harp;
and all sing, or would sing if they were taught, or sing all the better
for not being taught; or something like it.']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText: I know nothing of the Miss Owens,
subQuotationList: ['I know nothing of the Miss Owens,']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
You know nothing and you care less, as people say. Never did tone
express indifference plainer. Indeed, how can one care for those one
has never seen? Well, when your cousin comes back, he will find
Mansfield very quiet; all the noisy ones gone, your brother and mine
and myself. I do not like the idea of leaving Mrs. Grant now the time
draws near. She does not like my going.
subQuotationList:
['You know nothing and you care less, as people say. Never did tone
express indifference plainer. Indeed, how can one care for those one
has never seen? Well, when your cousin comes back, he will find

and myself. I do not like the idea of leaving Mrs. Grant now the time
draws near. She does not like my going.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Edmund'], ['Edmund'], ['William Price'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Mrs. Grant'], ['Mrs. Grant']]]

quoteText:
You cannot doubt your being missed by
many, You will be very much missed.
subQuotationList: ['You cannot doubt your being missed by\nmany,', 'You will be very much missed.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Oh yes! missed as every noisy evil is missed
when it is taken away; that is, there is a great difference felt. But I
am not fishing; don't compliment me. If I _am_ missed, it will appear.
I may be discovered by those who want to see me. I shall not be in any
doubtful, or distant, or unapproachable region.
subQuotationList:
["Oh yes! missed as every noisy evil is missed
when it is taken away; that is, there is a great difference felt. But I
am not fishing; don't compliment me. If I _am_ missed, it will appear.

doubtful, or distant, or unapproachable region."]

referringExpression: Miss Crawford turned her eye on her as if wanting to hear or see more and then laughingly said

quoteText:
The Miss Owens, suppose you were to have
one of the Miss Owens settled at Thornton Lacey; how should you like
it? Stranger things have happened. I dare say they are trying for it.
And they are quite in the right, for it would be a very pretty
establishment for them. I do not at all wonder or blame them. It is
everybody's duty to do as well for themselves as they can. Sir Thomas
Bertram's son is somebody; and now he is in their own line. Their
father is a clergyman, and their brother is a clergyman, and they are
all clergymen together. He is their lawful property; he fairly belongs
to them. You don't speak, Fanny; Miss Price, you don't speak. But
honestly now, do not you rather expect it than otherwise?

quoteText: No, I do not expect it at all.
subQuotationList: ['No,', 'I do not expect it at all.']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
Not at all! I wonder at that. But
I dare say you know exactly   I always imagine you are   perhaps you do not

subQuotationList: ['Not at all!', 'I wonder at that. But\nI dare say you know exactly   I always imagine you are   perhaps you do not\nthink him likely to marry at all   or not at present.']

quoteText: No, I do not,
subQuotationList: ['No, I do not,']
speaker: Fanny Price

quoteText:
He is best off as
he is,
subQuotationList: ['He is best off as\nhe is,']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: Her companion looked at her keenly and gathering greater spirit from the blush soon produced from such a look only said

quoteText:
My dear Henry, where can you
have been all this time?
subQuotationList: ['My dear Henry, where can you\nhave been all this time?']
speaker: Mary Crawford
referringExpression: his sister who had been waiting for him to walk with her in the garden met him at last most impatiently in the sweep and cried out

quoteText: Sitting with them an hour and a half!
subQuotationList: ['Sitting with them an hour and a half!']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
Yes, Mary, I could not get away sooner;
Fanny looked so lovely! I am quite determined, Mary. My mind is
entirely made up. Will it astonish you? No: you must be aware that I am
quite determined to marry Fanny Price.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, Mary,', 'I could not get away sooner;
Fanny looked so lovely! I am quite determined, Mary. My mind is
entirely made up. Will it astonish you? No: you must be aware that I am
quite determined to marry Fanny Price.']
speaker: Henry Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Mary Crawford']], [['Fanny Price'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Mary Crawford'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
Yes, Mary, I am fairly caught. You
know with what idle designs I began; but this is the end of them. I
have, I flatter myself, made no inconsiderable progress in her
affections; but my own are entirely fixed.
subQuotationList:
['Yes, Mary,', 'I am fairly caught. You
know with what idle designs I began; but this is the end of them. I
have, I flatter myself, made no inconsiderable progress in her
affections; but my own are entirely fixed.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Lucky, lucky girl! what a
match for her! My dearest Henry, this must be my _first_ feeling; but
my _second_, which you shall have as sincerely, is, that I approve your
choice from my soul, and foresee your happiness as heartily as I wish
and desire it. You will have a sweet little wife; all gratitude and
devotion. Exactly what you deserve. What an amazing match for her! Mrs.
Norris often talks of her luck; what will she say now? The delight of
all the family, indeed! And she has some _true_ friends in it! How
_they_ will rejoice! But tell me all about it! Talk to me for ever.
When did you begin to think seriously about her?

quoteText:
Ah, my dear
Henry, and this is what took you to London! This was your business! You
chose to consult the Admiral before you made up your mind.
subQuotationList: ['Ah, my dear\nHenry, and this is what took you to London! This was your business! You\nchose to consult the Admiral before you made up your mind.']
speaker: Mary Crawford
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Admiral Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford'], ['Henry Crawford']]]

quoteText:
When Fanny is known to him, he will doat on her.
She is exactly the woman to do away every prejudice of such a man as
the Admiral, for she is exactly such a woman as he thinks does not
exist in the world. She is the very impossibility he would describe, if
indeed he has now delicacy of language enough to embody his own ideas.
But till it is absolutely settled   settled beyond all interference, he
shall know nothing of the matter. No, Mary, you are quite mistaken. You
have not discovered my business yet.

quoteText:
Well, well, I am satisfied. I know now to whom it must relate, and am
in no hurry for the rest. Fanny Price! wonderful, quite wonderful! That
Mansfield should have done so much for   that _you_ should have found
your fate in Mansfield! But you are quite right; you could not have
chosen better. There is not a better girl in the world, and you do not
want for fortune; and as to her connexions, they are more than good.
The Bertrams are undoubtedly some of the first people in this country.
She is niece to Sir Thomas Bertram; that will be enough for the world.
But go on, go on. Tell me more. What are your plans? Does she know her
own happiness?

quoteText: No.
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText: What are you waiting for?
subQuotationList: ['What are you waiting for?']
speaker: Mary Crawford

quoteText:
For   for very little more than opportunity. Mary, she is not like her
cousins; but I think I shall not ask in vain.
subQuotationList: ['For   for very little more than opportunity. Mary, she is not like her\ncousins; but I think I shall not ask in vain.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
Oh no! you cannot. Were you even less pleasing   supposing her not to
love you already (of which, however, I can have little doubt)   you would
be safe. The gentleness and gratitude of her disposition would secure
her all your own immediately. From my soul I do not think she would
marry you _without_ love; that is, if there is a girl in the world
capable of being uninfluenced by ambition, I can suppose it her; but
ask her to love you, and she will never have the heart to refuse.

mentionEntitiesList: [[['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price'], ['Fanny Price']]]

quoteText:
I could so wholly and absolutely confide in her, and _that_
is what I want.
subQuotationList: ['I could so wholly and absolutely confide in her,', 'and _that_\nis what I want.']
speaker: Henry Crawford

quoteText:
The more I think of it, the more am I convinced that you
are doing quite right; and though I should never have selected Fanny
Price as the girl most likely to attach you, I am now persuaded she is
the very one to make you happy. Your wicked project upon her peace
turns out a clever thought indeed. You will both find your good in it.
subQuotationList:
['The more I think of it,', 'the more am I convinced that you
are doing quite right; and though I should never have selected Fanny
Price as the girl most likely to attach you, I am now persuaded she is
